Charnotes: With the draft dittay it definitely seems to be neighbourhood dispute.
DevilNotes: Was witnessed by 5 people, the pin was stuck up to its head with no sensation and no blood.
MeetingNotes: She said at the meeting they 'sought the good of the fruits of ye ground and fisheing af ye sea from Sathan'.  And they supposedly drank porter at the meeting at the Kirk of Irvine.
FolkNotes: Walked Widdershins.
DiseaseNotes: Caused a drunken man to beat his wife. Destroyed alehouse ale after she was refused a pint. Destroyed someone else's ale. A lot of quarrels.

Charnotes: She predicted the death of the regent.
DevilNotes: She called a spirit to help her heal, he came to her like a great blast of whirlwind. The spirit was the ghost of a woman who had taught her how to heal.  It is possible that she too was a fairy?
MeetingNotes: She was seen in a great company of women by a sick man.
FolkNotes: Used shirt for diagnosis.  Brought the shirt to an elvish well.  She charged the spirit in the name of the father, the son, king Arthur and queen Elspeth to remove the illness or take the sick man to them.  She couldn't do a cure because it was past Halloween.  Predicted the death of an infant because she got a blast of evil wind.  She learned her curing from a woman in the Potterrow who had once cured her.  She started her prayer with 'Blist Benedicite'.  After she washed her hands at a holy well, St. Leonards, there came to her a man of our good neighbours.  Predicted that the Regent would die.  She bore five bairns while subject to the fairy for seven years and felt no pain.
DiseaseNotes: Could heal children that were taken away with the fairy (?changelings) and many other diseases.

DevilNotes: With the Devil.

Charnotes: Alastair Hendry has Thom Reid, the man Bessie claimed to learn her craft from, as an Officiare (barony officer) to the Lord of Blair, and killed at the Battle of Pinkie, 10/9/1547.  Not sure he was a real person and he pre-dates the survey so I have not made a separate reference for him. Although she confessed to renunciation of baptism we have not ticked demonic as a secondary characterisation as the case was more about fairies than demonic material.
DevilNotes: Thom Reid was described as having died at Pinkie.  She described as a good, elderly man in grey clothes, grey brekins (trousers), white shanks, a black hand, with a white wand.  Thom Reid asked her to 'trow' (trust in) him and give up Christianity.  She would not do it, but offered to be true in every other way.
MeetingNotes: Thom came to her when she was lamenting the sickness of her cows, husband and children and the land-ill (famine?).  She had just risen out of child-bed.  He told her to mend her ways with God, what would happen and then disappeared into a hole.
FolkNotes: She was told to be silent about her visit to the fairies.  There were 12 of them, 8 women and 4 men.  Indication of how she was questioned to get accomplices and more information.  The fairies wanted her to go with them.  Loads of information about fairies.  Specific roots and herbs were mentioned, including ginger, liquorice, clover, and anis seed.  Thom gave her a green thread to help with child birth curing but she lost it.  They asked if she supported the Reformed faith, she said that Thom said it was not good, but the old faith needed fixing.  12:00 hour of the day was Thom's most common time to appear.  The Queen of Elphan commanded him to wait upon her.  She was asked specifically if she met him by lochs and water side, she said only once.
DiseaseNotes: Claimed she could accomplish things with the help of Thom Reid (her ghost). He taught her about herbs. Was paid in kind for her healing. Confessed to healing quite rich people.  Was asked if she could help with child-birth, said she lost the green thread.

DevilNotes: She held the Devil's hand but was frightened. His hand was cold.
MeetingNotes: She was questioned about other people at witches' meetings, She did not know who the women in white and grey were, but the woman in white might have been Elspett Black. Investigators wanted to know who the woman with the black pock was, ?possibly Katherine Kay.  They danced in a ring at a meeting.
FolkNotes: Woman in green waiscoat with a black pot ?fairy.  Joined the devil during Lenten.
CaseNotes: K. Remy, B. Paton, and M. Tailior were extrajudicially tortured and burnt with hot stones by four local men.  The JPs questioned them, and confronted them with the three witchcraft suspects.  No further action was taken.

Charnotes: She denied all charges related to demonic pact.  She was denounced by at least four people.
DevilNotes: Margaret Talzeor claimed that Paton had been at meetings with the devil. Paton denied all charges related to demonic pact, although she did admit that she might have been carried to meetings as a spirit while she was asleep.
MeetingNotes: Supposedly killed two bairns and a cat. The woman with the black pock was there, Katherine Kay.  She denounced people and gave specific details.  They killed the bairns with meal that was in the black pock/pot.
FolkNotes: Described how Sybilla Drummond had told her to use salt and south running water for a woman in labour.  Accused of putting raw flesh under a threshold to kill animals.  She put a clout in a hole in a man's wall.
DiseaseNotes: Denied all charges of malefice but confessed that she had been instructed to go to another woman in Dunblane (Sybilla Drummond) for advice about a woman in labour. Woman later died.
CaseNotes: K. Remy, B. Paton, and M. Tailior were extrajudicially tortured and burnt with hot stones by four local men.  The JPs questioned them, and confronted them with the three witchcraft suspects.  No further action was taken.

DevilNotes: Did not confess to any features of demonic pact to the presbytery but they implied it.  She later did confess to a demonic pact.  She was heard yelling to Satan to get out of her bed.
MeetingNotes: The Devil went home with her in a great storm
FolkNotes: Confessed some story about having a moldiewort that she kept at home ?familiar but unlikely.  A woman saw a woman walking home from where they collected mussels, looked back and saw only a sow, and 'in the twinkling of an eye' she saw no sow but Jonet Black.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused of damaging the boat at Black grange while in the shape of a corbie.

Charnotes: Denounced by Margaret Duchall and confessed to demonic pact.
DevilNotes: Confessed the devil's name was Johne. At one meeting there was a gentlewoman whose name she did not know. The woman had a black pot and wore a green waistcoat with grey tails. In second confession described touching her head and foot
MeetingNotes: She described many meetings with various combinations of other people. Also said that they spoke in another language.  Had a meeting in a brewhouse
FolkNotes: Claimed that Jonet Great, who was dead, came out with herself and others to a man's house, where they stole bread
DiseaseNotes: Claimed that the other woman had told her about malefice (death of animals and children) but did not confess to any herself the first time. Later she claimed that they had destroyed a child and animals.
CaseNotes: K. Remy, B. Paton, and M. Tailior were extrajudicially tortured and burnt with hot stones by four local men.  The JPs questioned them, and confronted them with the three witchcraft suspects.  No further action was taken.

She was tried twice (with two others).  In her first trial on 23/3/1659 in the circuit court she was found guilty and ordered to be transported.  Until that could be arranged she was to be held in Stirling prison.  Apparently after two years of imprisonment they petitioned privy council, who ordered another trial due to irregularities in the first one.  The second trial was a local one, we don't know the outcome.

DevilNotes: Claimed the devil was called 'Johne'. He lay on top of her cow and was like a cow.
MeetingNotes: Several meetings at various places. Often met at the house of the person who they intended to harm
FolkNotes: Often met the devil and others at 12 o'clock at night.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed that she complained to the devil about people who had insulted her or owed the group money and the devil would punish them and kill them. Caused death of people and animals. Took a man and tried to drown him.

Charnotes: Witness statements said that people overheard her talking about the Devil.  But not enough information to make a solid characterisation.
DevilNotes: Mention of giving her daughter over to the Devil. The circuit court handwritting is difficult to make out.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of malefices.
CaseNotes: She was ordered to be released from prison on 28/12/1658 due to ill health (bloody flux).  She was tried twice (with two others).  In her first trial on 23/3/1659 in the circuit court she was found guilty and ordered to be transported.  Until that could be arranged she was to be held in Stirling prison.  Apparently after two years of imprisonment they petitioned privy council, who ordered another trial due to irregularities in the first trial.  The second trial was a local one, we don't know the outcome.
Notes on her case go from 1643 to 1658.

DevilNotes: Confessed to being with the Devil.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#289) as being from JC26/26 C.  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box and did not find the case.  Larner has this case as mentioned as a witch in someone else's trial.  That means we do not have a trial record for this person.

Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#290) as being from JC26/26 C.  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box and did not find the case.  Larner has this case as mentioned as a witch in someone else's trial.  That means we do not have a trial record for this person.

DevilNotes: A man in black was at the food party, but doesn't specify that it was the Devil.
MeetingNotes: A description of a table laid out with 'boylies, beif and bread' at M. Gourley's house.  Janet was offered food but refused.  Doesn't specify that it was a witches meeting.  Suspicious things were seen, a black corbie with a black man.
FolkNotes: Confessed to doing something with woollen yarn placed around, the text is unclear.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: She was accused of being an accomplice to Gourley's (c/egd/308) firestarting.  She claimed that she and Gourley took 5 burning coals and put them in places of the house that burnt down.

Charnotes: Denounced by Janet Millar (c/egd/307).
MeetingNotes: Jonet Millar, described a table laid out with 'boylies, beif and bread' at M. Gourlay's house.  Janet was offered food but refused.  Doesn't specify that it was a witches meeting.  Suspicious things were seen, including a black corbie with a black man.
FolkNotes: Accused of tampering with someone's hearth fire and causing a fire.

MeetingNotes: They danced in a ring around the broadstone in Gallowhop.  She asked the Devil to get amends of a soldier that quartered in her house, he agreed to get rid of the English man.  She drank wine with Simon the Devil.  Wanted amends of a wobster who kept her cloth over a year, and amends of a minister for a debt.
DiseaseNotes: Wanted amends of people who crossed her from the Devil. Those people suffered.

Charnotes: She was accused of trying to kill the Regent with witchcraft.

DevilNotes: He promised her amends.  Devil put his hand on her shoulder and left a pain.
MeetingNotes: They danced in a ring. She confessed that she fell and the Devil took her up the hand (Lacost testified about this prior to her confession!).  They drank ale and wine that they stole. Meeting around the broadstones at Gallowhop, asked for amends for a man who stole meal.  Wanted amends on the English because they took her to the grange and left her there. Devil couldn't help because they were no longer in Scotland. [so did the Devil only have power in Scotland?]
She wanted amends for a peck of peace (?peas) that was stolen from her.

DevilNotes: Devil went to her at her bedside.
MeetingNotes: People met in Mr. Robert's Close to drink ale in the evening (don't think this is meant to be a witches' meeting?).  After Lacost was arrested they all met in William Henderson's barn in Stenton and a man with grey clothes told them to deny everything.  Dispute about lint with the minister's wife and the Devil was asked for amends.
DiseaseNotes: Dispute about lint with the minister's wife.  Denied everything except that the wife took lint from her.

DevilNotes: She was 'seriously exhorted' to tell the truth about her relations with the Devil.
MeetingNotes: They 'had a feast' of ale and wheat bread at meetings.
CaseNotes: Not sure when she was tried?

MeetingNotes: Claimed by other confessing accused that she drank ale at a man's house and got wine. They said she wanted to get revenge for a debt, the Devil said no because of his good prayer. She also wanted revenge for someone not marrying her. Wood denied it all.

Charnotes: denounced by Jonet Millar (c/egd/307).
FolkNotes: A woman went to her for advice on how to cure her daughter.  Margaret told her to put something above her door, which the woman refused and her daughter died.

Charnotes: It is simply a list of people and whether or not they ratified their witness statements.  Impossible to tell what the dittay said.  We have a document called the Manner of the Charmes of the Stirling Witches, lots of descriptions!
FolkNotes: To cure blasted people, washed them with water from the hollow ground after an ebb in the sea with a quantity of meal and straw placed in four corners of the bed, and she used a horseshoe, a hook and a piece of raw flesh.  She said father, son and holy ghost three times.  To cure maw turned she walked people around an oak pole three times, said some words to God and St. Brisbane.  For curing someone that is wronged by an other at variance with them, go them and crave your health back (basically curing the quarrel, words, misfortune illnesses).  For keeping folks from harm, bury a quick modiewort  in a box under the outside of a threshold.

she knows a blasted person, which means a bewitched person 'by the gogling of their eyes and turning hither and tither to ather side.'  Washes their clothes in St. Ninian's well for healing.  This will either 'end them or mend them.'  She learned it from lady McFarlens daughter 24 years prior.  She transfers the disease if she meets anyone on the way back from the well.  Also layed two foxtree leaves under their head and middle.  She cures maw turning by leading people around an oak tree three times, repeating words.  For curing persons forespoken she recites words and takes some of the illness into herself.  For curing heart fires she uses a belt and two threads she rolls them and if the threads are on the top and the bottom the person has heart fires.

DevilNotes: Saw the Devil in her bed, implied sex.
MeetingNotes: When describing a meeting (presumably in response to being asked to name names) she said, there were 40 women at the meeting but they were behind a mist and the place where the men were was also covered in mist.  She said that Fermor came to her while sleeping and took her to a meeting.

DevilNotes: When seeking alms from Fermor, Fermor told Jonnet that there was a better way to live and introduced her to the Devil in grey clothes who looked like a gentleman.  She confessed that the Devil locked her heart until a minister prayed and she received peace.
MeetingNotes: Said there were 11 people at her meeting.  The Devil was angry when she was away (when she missed a meeting?).

CaseNotes: His case was refered to the the Justiciar of Ayr for trial.

DiseaseNotes: She struck a man in the face with a kaird (comb used to prepare wool) to the 'efusion of his blood'.

DevilNotes: He appeared uglier and bigger each time she saw him. He came in through a locked door at midnight.
MeetingNotes: She saw the Devil with a group of people while she was gathering snails in the morning.  Doesn't seem like a witches' meeting.
FolkNotes: She used Foxtree leaves and told people to ask for their health from a suspected witch for God's sake. Used south running water

MeetingNotes: Fowler said she saw Cochrane at a meeting at the Bragreen between Tranent and Seton, Cochrane denied.  Eventually confessed that she met the Devil at Maitland feast.

Charnotes: She was consulted by a group of people to get revenge.
MeetingNotes: She was alone in the Glen and bitten by dogs out for a hunt while she was in the shape of a badger.  They later found her in human form with lots of bites on her mouth and hide parts.
FolkNotes: Her purse was found by a man in town, and it contained pickles of quheit beir (wheat bere), great salt pieces, pieces of coal, thread, joint bones, and other things of various colours.  She used the shear and riddle (sieve) to get gear for people.
DiseaseNotes: Threatened a man who found and opened her purse, he died.  She diagnosed his lamb problem  Accused of killing 10 people.
CaseNotes: She was tried and banished, and then a new indictment was drawn up later that incorporated that guilty verdict as item 8.

DevilNotes: Devil met her at Dalkeith and Gibbert.  On the way home from Edinburgh he was lying in a brown bush at 12pm.
MeetingNotes: Meeting in a brown bush and she met him while running out of the mill.
FolkNotes: Meeting in a brown bush at midday 12 noon.

CaseNotes: Check up on county and date from JC26/26 (8)?  Definitely in JC26/26, not sure if this is the same Katharine Gray as the one mentioned by Issobel Young? [addition in 2003 - she is not the one mentioned by Young!  Katherine Quay mentioned as burnt in haddington by 1629 JC26/9/1]

MeetingNotes: She confessed to being taken our of her body for a meeting.

DevilNotes: Devil was described as lying heavy upon her while she was in bed with Helen Speiris, another mentioned witch.

CaseNotes: The project did not check Larner's reference to this printed secondary source as part of the research.

Charnotes: She was delated by Janet Watsone
DevilNotes: Met the devil after discord with her husband.  She knew it was the Devil because he vanished more quickly than a normal man.
MeetingNotes: meeting happened on 'beal fire night' (Beltane)

Charnotes: There is talk of healing but the main just seems to be the fairies and the mysterious Mr. William Sympson, who was either a fairy or some other kind of healer/teacher figure.  Can't tell if he was a real person or not, but I made a record for him (c/la/2894). Maleficium ticked as it was said the Archbishop of St Andrews had died after she gave him the herbal tea - so it may have been failed healing rather than deliberate malefice. Although she made a pact it was with fairies therefore we did not tick demonic as a secondary since it was not clear that it was a straightforward demonic relationship.
DevilNotes: A man came to her when she was sick and she promised to be faithful in order to get help from him.  She was not allowed to speak about it or they would go away and she would go to hell.  Described the fairies giving her a mark that felt no pain.
MeetingNotes: She laid down sick in the Grange-mure and a man in green clothes came to her.  She described meetings with fairies that sound a lot like later descriptions of Sabbath.  She asked if they were in God's name, when they weren't she left, but she eventually joined them.
FolkNotes: She was cured by this Mr. William sympson 'the witch', Mr. Sympson made a statement about all the illnesses of the Archbishop of St. Andrews.  Said she had friends in the court of the fairies who were blood relations.  She couldn't recall how long she had spent with the fairies.  The good neighbours hold her under God. She claimed to go to St. Andrews to heal people.
DiseaseNotes: She was to make a salve and rub it on the Archbishop of St. Andrews. She mixed herbs in a tea, the bishop drank it and died. Her cousin cured her when the power was taken from her hand and foot.  She saw the good neighbours make their salves with fire.

DevilNotes: She met the Devil at harvest.
The Devil first appeared to her as rat and she scared it away, then he changed into a man and lay heavy on her as she slept.
FolkNotes: She Devil changed shape from a rat into a man.

DevilNotes: He changed from a cow to a man in green clothes.
MeetingNotes: There were about 10 or 11 other people at the Deane, but she couldn't see them.
FolkNotes: A woman took her to the Deane, a place called the stone well.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed to being a frequent curser and blasphemer of her husband and children.  Witnesses testified to this.

DevilNotes: The Devil appeared at his house at 10:00pm and asked him if he would be a piper to his servants, and he nipped Douglas' neck.
MeetingNotes: Douglas played the pipes at the meetings.

Charnotes: She referred to her female associates as hussie (hizzie=housewife, mistress, which has bad connotations]
DevilNotes: Devil appeared to her when she was drawing water at a well in Tranent in the morning.  Devil said he would pay her.  They threw water in her face and called her Lapie in the name of Beelzebub.

Charnotes: She was delated by Elspeth Fouller.
DevilNotes: She met the Devil in the black gutter.
MeetingNotes: Two people at the meeting played on two slate stones.

DevilNotes: The Devil took her by the finger.
MeetingNotes: The other participants were masked.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#340) as being from JC26/26 3.  Larner has this case as mentioned as a witch in someone else's trial.  That means we do not have a trial record for this person. This case is mentioned in Larner with those named by James Welch. II searched extensively for this name and did not find it.

FolkNotes: Confessed to going to a witches' meeting on Lammas.

Charnotes: Another accused witch claimed he played the whistle at meetings.
MeetingNotes: Margaret Talzeor claimed that Kirk played the whistle at their meetings.
Meeting on the last beal fire night (i.e. Beltane)

Charnotes: May have confessed to pact
DevilNotes: Did not renounce her baptism.

CaseNotes: Could not find these in the source referenced by Larner.
Could not find the sources referenced by Larner.

DevilNotes: Pact was in exchange for a new petticoat, and she confessed that the Devil as a '[?] gentleman' had come over the water to the colliers.  She was called Clear Keys because she had keys with her, according to her confession.
CaseNotes: Larner has another Janet Daill from Moffat Dumfries listed with a Thomas Wilson the date of 16/7/1661.  I didn't find these cases.

DevilNotes: Went to him because of her poverty.  Received a stone from the Devil.  Had pain after receiving the mark.  Said his nature was cold after sex.
Got the mark when the Devil put his finger on his leg.

Strange one; the Devil wanted her to keep his house because his previous wife had died. He gave her silver which turned into stone.  She denied having a mark although they found one on her.  She confessed to getting paid for her service to the Devil.
MeetingNotes: Said there were many other 'masked folkes' there.
DiseaseNotes: denied committing any malefice

DevilNotes: Met the Devil in the house of a friend who introduced them, they all shared a cup of ale.
DiseaseNotes: Said she had committed no malefice

Charnotes: She was denounced by Elspet Millar and Grissel Scot from Newton (c/la/2799, c/la/2800)
DevilNotes: Received money from the Devil, which disappeared when he left (around 40 pennies).

Charnotes: May have confessed to demonic pact.
DevilNotes: She retracted all this stuff that she had originally confessed.

CaseNotes: Familiars of Lady Fowlis.

Charnotes: Hard to tell what was going on, but a lot of devil stuff.  She was delated by Jonet Watson (c/egd/365)
DevilNotes: The Devil appeared when she was angry with her son.  She spoke with the Devil in the form of a black dog at the mill while her daughter was there.  The devil kissed her and called her buntein (buntin = plump, short, dumpy).
MeetingNotes: The meeting at the dam was supposedly on the 'last beal fire night' meaning Beltane.  Confession document has some descriptions of these meetings.
FolkNotes: Definite fairy things here: Devil in green clothes and a witches meeting on Beltane night.

Charnotes: I think that under questioning, etc. she retold an fornication or adultery episode as a meeting with the Devil. The accusations made to the KS include verbal threats against her neighbours and her own son.
DevilNotes: William Twedie, the Devil, gave her a pair of black gloves.  She denied that Devil laid with her.  There were two William Tweedies, her landlord and his evil half brother.  Some confusion, she confessed to having an affair with the half brother who fled to 'Irland'  this person was always present when the met the Devil and the Devil didn't appear after he had left.  I he morphed into the Devil for her.
DiseaseNotes: Seems to have threatened her neighbours. Told them they would be poor, their horse took ill and they were reduced to poverty. Also angry about her son and told his wife he would have a bad homecoming. On his return he took ill and died.
CaseNotes: She may have gotten caught up in the witch panic because she was already a accused of fornication and adultery.  The Devil as william twedie could likely be a re-telling of an adulterous affair.  Also, she used to live in Liberton Parish, so that maybe the connection between the Dalkeith and Liberton witches?  Fergusson denounced a few Dalkeith people, that may have started the chain?

DevilNotes: This same information is in the JC2 and JC26/27/9 item 5.

DiseaseNotes: threatened that a woman would remain childless; confessed to killing her brother saying that she was worthy of death for that reason, fall outs, cursing, death
CaseNotes: The main issue in her case was that she killed her brother, for which she expressed extreme remorse and thought she should die (lots of witnesses testified to this).  She seemed to have lived with her brother at the time, more likely she lived just next door, perhaps in a semi-attached kind of house.  She had many conflicts within her immediate family, her brother and a nephew.

Charnotes: its all about the Devil
DevilNotes: the Devil changed from a beast to man to get into bed with her.  The draft dittay says she saw the Devil in her own house as a man with a meikle headed body.  Very detailed confession concerning sex with the Devil.

Charnotes: Her charges seem to have stemmed from disputes about her pock with her neighbours.  She also had disputes about the death of her cat, and she seemed to have been a midwife, but it was the disputes that seem to be the crux.  In her confession she was interrogated about her midwife practices, but she said there was no ill in them.  She was delated by Issobel Fergusson
DevilNotes: Someone testified that they saw a strange cat standing on its hind legs (implying that it was Beatrix).
FolkNotes: After a quarrel about Beatrix storing a pock in the house of William Young and Agnes his wife, they tried to appease her with ale. She drank but wouldn't speak. Later Beatrix ,as an apparition cat, attacked him, and their children were hurt in the coal pit.  She said that after meeting the devil she was frequently carried in her sleep to the company of many brave souls.  She practised definite rituals in midwifery. She stuck a baro knife between the bed and the straw and sprinkled salt and saying words.
DiseaseNotes: Quarrelled and cursed, harm followed. The two wifes that suffered harm had also killed Beatrix's cat. The coal pit collapsed  The deaths were in revenge for killing her cat.  Tried to heal her cow by rubbing a sick woman's shirt on it.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Burned down a house
DefenseNotes: She claimed that the Devil never promised her anything and that she was prone to fits of madness.
CaseNotes: She was accused of causing death through the collapse of the coal pit.  She must have lived near the pit and been a part of the pit community?

DevilNotes: Devil gave her 12 while she was gathering sticks, but it turned into stone.  She confessed that the Devil rang a bell to call her.
MeetingNotes: They had a meeting while she was gathering sticks.

DevilNotes: Devil came in black clothes like a gentleman, and looked like her husband.
Put her hand on her head.
MeetingNotes: She confessed that the meeting happened around 10:00pm in Gilmerton ward with 40 other masked people.

DevilNotes: Devil appeared to him at night while he was in bed. He was described as lying upon him heavy in the shape of a man.

Charnotes: Her stepsonHector wanted her terce.  She was accused of wanting to dispose of heirs.  She was accused of using poisoned drinks.  And of sending a servant to the Egyptians for poison.
FolkNotes: Accused of sending a man to the Egyptians for poison.  Made a picture of her victim out of butter.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing two heirs.  Accused of repeatedly trying to kill rival members of her family especially with poison, wax images, etc.
CaseNotes: Hector wanted her terce.  A good description of family connections, etc. in Pitcairn, vol 1, part ii, page 191.  She fled to Caithness when all her accomplices were tried and convicted.

DiseaseNotes: Became angry when her husband sold a cow.

DevilNotes: The Devil bade her remove something unreadable, probably an item of clothing.  She found his nature cold.

Charnotes: Pact confessed but few other details
DevilNotes: Devil as man lay down with her and he was as heavy as a millstone. He offered her money which she did not receive.

Accused of having carnal copulation with the devil and abusing her body, which should have been a 'temple to the Holy Ghost'. The devil gave her a dollar which later turned out to be 'sklait stone. The appearance of the devil is not described.
MeetingNotes: The devil told her to meet with him and her neighbours.

Charnotes: Pact confessed but few other details of charges.
DevilNotes: Devil was cold to touch. Met him at 11 am.
Devil arose out of the water at Tweedsyde and helped her over it for a meeting.
MeetingNotes: Meeting between 11 and 12 at night at the 'green dykes'.  This could be a ditch or a turf boundary wall (more likely the latter).  Also met the Devil when she was coming from Edinburgh through the park.

Charnotes: He was accused of having to kill his brother in order to cure himself.
FolkNotes: He hired people to kill  his brother Robert Munro, the same person that Lady Fowlis was trying to kill.

Charnotes: Seems to have had a reputation and people wanted to stay away from her, unclear why. With so many witnesses and disputes over land it is possible that this was a neighbourhood dispute.
MeetingNotes: A group of witches blew up a locked door and wanted to take a woman's new born baby during her lying in period, but they had no power and left in confusion.
FolkNotes: Accused of using orations to make Mungo Steill ill, but no description. Met the devil at dusk. Went down on her knees and cursed a man.
DiseaseNotes: Dispute over entitlement (tailzie) of a piece of land. Threatened man who later took ill. Two animals died after man refused to sell her a sheep or a horse.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of using charms, sorcery and witchcraft

Charnotes: Denounced under oath by Jannet Ker and Marjorie Fairwell.  Confessed pact with devil
DevilNotes: She sent three cats to someone's house to make noise and cause illness. The devil promised her money. Devil took her in his arms ?sexual implication.
FolkNotes: A male victim suffering from pains like child birth and swelling went to a English doctor in Leith,  who declared that he was bewitched.  New charges in second restatement of trial.  Her master Andro Lauder and his wife asked if she had fallen out with anyone. Disease was taken off and moved to a cat, there was a cold wind when the cat died.
DiseaseNotes: A piece of raw flesh was found under a male victims loom after he chased Hutchison off his land, which when cast in the fire caused a loud noise and the death of his cat.  Aflicted a whole household after a competition between male head and her husband.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Caused a man to have pains like a women in child birth.  Suffocated a new born child at midnight when she was in apparition form after appearing for 8 nights.  Tried to kill a woman who wouldn't return her cauldron, but killed her dog by mistake.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of harming people and goods by using charms, sorcery and witchcraft.
DefenseNotes: No words or deeds. Defence argued relevancy of accusations: witchcraft or nature.

Charnotes: Demonic pact featured in detail although malefice also important.
DevilNotes: Devil gave her a sixpence which she used to buy meal.  Probably sex implied because the Devil supposedly appeared to her in her bed in the likeness of her husband. Gave her a dollar which she said later turned to 'sklait stane'. She denied that she had renounced her baptism.
FolkNotes: Appeasement was tried but failed. Claimed by witness that a cat (?Ramsay) appeared 3 times in his house and that later 2 of his boys died and his wife was ill for 26 weeks.
DiseaseNotes: A youngish girl dropped her' kitt' on Ramsay's brow causing a headache. Ramsay cursed the girl, whose mother tried to reconcile with Ramsay, but failed. The girl was blown over by a blast of wind and lost the power of her hand.
OtherChargesNotes: By 'charmes and malifices' she caused the death of many people.

MeetingNotes: Taken to a meeting in the hills, by a whirl wind.  She masked herself at her meeting and was assigned a certain number of a malifices.

Charnotes: Her case doesn't even seem to a real case.  She hints that she is only guilty of having sex with several different men.  She claims they weren't the Devil and she didn't renounce her baptism or become anyone's servant.
DevilNotes: Said that she had sex with someone three times.  She claimed it was not the Devil but Henry Bear.  But she said he was cold the first two times.  She said she heard a bee and a butterfly. She refused to be the Devil's servant.  Unclear, very vague pact stuff.

CaseNotes: She was ordered released from prison on caution not to use charms, sorcery or witchcraft again.

Charnotes: Some information about quarrelling with neighbours over borrowed money, and working conditions.
DevilNotes: Devil promised her all the pleasure in the world.
CaseNotes: She was ordered released from prison on caution not to use charms, sorcery or witchcraft again.

Charnotes: She was a party to several healing attempts that transferred the disease on to a child and a dog.  She was not the main person, but an assistant.  In second trial she appears more of a healer, turning up when people were ill (or bewitched by a different witch) and offering a diagnosis and cure.  Neighbourhood dispute is the dominant trend. 2 violent altercations between Janet and her accusers are described in the 2nd trial.
DevilNotes: Devil went away from her in whirl of wind.
FolkNotes: After a horse fell ill, 'a country man' said that if they put the horses' shoes in a red hot fire and took them out, the bewitcher would appear if it was witchcraft, then Janet Cock showed up without a pretext.  When Janet Cock appeared above a new mother and her child, the new mother said 'the spirit of grace be in this house' and the witches and devil disappeared.
DiseaseNotes: Tried to steal a new baby while mother was lying in.  Helped another witch transfer a disease from a child to a dog. Left a dish of blood and the dog was found decapitated. Her curses included: 'O! thame that called me a witch' and 'what rakis robin'
OtherMaleficiaNotes: In second trial, she was described as a 'skilled woman' in relation to healing and diagnosis of disease.  Diagnosed with 'gripping' and prescribed cures.  She cured a cold and colic using 'black wool', garlic and aqua vitae, and forbade prayer.
CaseNotes: First trial she was acquitted, second trial convicted.  The make up of the assize in first trial was 7 from Edinburgh, 1 from Canongate, 7 from Dalkeith.  For the second trial it was 6 from Edinburgh, 1 from Canongate, 8 from Dalkieth - giving the Dalkeithers a swing vote.  The first chancellor was from Edinburgh, the second from Dalkeith.  Someone wanted her to be found guilty and changed the jury by just one person.

Charnotes: She was hired to cure Hector Munro, but in order to do that he had to have his brother die in his place.
DevilNotes: Mention of the her master the Devil, but no details.
DiseaseNotes: She said she could cure Hector Munro but one of his blood would have to die. He chose his brother.

DevilNotes: Devil gave her a kiss.  A servant saw a black man go into Margaret's room and he moved around like he had oxen feet.
MeetingNotes: Haddington was written first and then crossed out and replaced with Hodin dean two words.
DiseaseNotes: She was described as being 'like dead' when her victims suffered a trembling and sweating ailment.
CaseNotes: Strange one: the prosecutor was a local laird, who dropped the prosecution in exchange for banishment.

Charnotes: All of the accusations against her revolved around business type dealings, land, borrowing money, payments in kind.  She seemed to have been suspected of witchcraft after many convicted witches accused her. The accusations were believable because of quarrels followed by harm.  Many documents mention her common repute as a witch.  She was previously denounced in 1649 with no mention of what happened there.  She was denounced by James Welch sometime before 1662. Petition to parliament from Earl of Haddington. He claimed that witchcraft was increasing in his lands and had imprisoned the suspects. He also claimed that two of them were accused of robbery as well.
DevilNotes: Accused of giving her newly born baby to the Devil and claiming that it had died in childbirth.  Confessed that she became a witch after discord with her husband.
MeetingNotes: Welch denounced her for being at a meeting at Haddington mill, and being at a meeting to destroy someone with two wisps at a barn door.
FolkNotes: Her husband offered ale to one of her accusers.
DiseaseNotes: She was heard to say 'a ha, a ha' before killing a horse by taking a piece of flesh the size of a golf ball out of its mouth and leaving pieces of flesh that looked like tobacco pipes nearby. She possibly deliberately aborted her pregnancy.
DefenseNotes: No acts alleged
CaseNotes: Part of the large number of people denounced by James Welch.  He was deemed too young to stand trial so he was imprisoned.  But his confession and some of his denunciations were taken seriously by the authorities.

Charnotes: He was a young boy who confessed to over 15 meetings with witches and the Devil and delated around 90 people.  His confessions involved the Devil and were most likely produced as the result of pressure exerted by the interrogators.
DevilNotes: Brought to the Devil by his mother and his good dame - grandmother  Doesnt way what their names were.
MeetingNotes: The first meeting at Haddington mill he just saw and it was after that he claimed he was brought to the Devil.  Didn't say where the second meeting was, but he was brought by his mother and good dame.  He confessed to drinking ale and wine at some meetings and eating meat.
CaseNotes: He denounced about 90 people from East Lothian sometime in 1661.

Charnotes: Hector Munro hired this group to cure his brother.
FolkNotes: Said by Hector Munro that he used hair and nail trimmings.

Charnotes: She was consulted by Katherine Ross, Lady Fowlis to destroy heirs.  She seems to have been Lady Fowlis' right-hand woman.  She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property.
DiseaseNotes: Poisoned ale.

CaseNotes: She was hired to kill someone.

Charnotes: She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property.

FolkNotes: He was sent to the Egyptians to get poison for Lady Ross. He was paid 8 shillings and some cloth.
DiseaseNotes: Was sent to Egyptians to get poison.  He supposedly bought poison in Tain, Ross and Elgin.

DevilNotes: She was accused of stealing gold and gold jewellery from her employer, the Laird of Balquhene (John Leslie).  She claimed that the Devil gave them to her.
FolkNotes: She did some kind of charm with a compass in the earth.  Three worms came out of a hole in the middle of the compass, a big one, a little one and then a big one that died.  She interpreted this as a man, his unknown infant in the womb, and his wife who would die of childbirth, and she did.
DiseaseNotes: Took away a woman's milk in order to prevent her from being a wet nurse.  She had a grudge against a particular family.
CaseNotes: Mentioned in a process note about Leslie and Achinleck.
She was listed in Larner along with some of the people denounced by James Welch, but I didn't find her.

CaseNotes: Several entries in the Privy Council record the length of imprisonment and pleas from the accused to the PC to order a speedy trial or release her. More commissioners added to list in 1666. BD again appealed to PC in 1667 and commissioners were ordered to explain to PC why no trial had been held. 7/5/1667 she was eventually released and ordered to attend for trial when she was called.

Charnotes: He was not accused of witchcraft at his High Court trial, but commentators after his death described him as a witch.
CaseNotes: Have not found evidence that he was actually tried for witchcraft.  He seems to have been tried for incest, adultery and beastiality. His sister was tried for withcraft, however.  Larner has transcribed a description of his life and death from The Fraser Manuscript, p. 307-312 in the National Library of Scotland, called 'a Collection of Providential Passages Antient and Modern Forreign and Domestick', dated 1670.  He is described as a warlock in this document - and there are vivid descriptions of his arrest and strange happenings with his possessions (his staff and two clouts that made dancing rings when burned).

Charnotes: I think she was investigated for the witchcraft, consulting and fairy contacts after the charge of incest was made public.
DevilNotes: She did not meet the devil as such, but dealt with a 'woman' described as most likely a spirit who was 'evidently the devil or a sorcerer'.
FolkNotes: The spirit woman offered to go to the queen of fairy to get help for Jean.  After receiving help from the woman who went to talk to the queen of fairy Jean was spinning and found a lot of money.
CaseNotes: Linked with the incest, bestiality and adultery charges launched at her brother.  He was convicted and executed.  But I found no mention of witchcraft in his trial transcript in JC2/13 f. 8v-9v.

Charnotes: She was delated by two other known witches as having consulted them for the murdering of her husbands.  She supposedly received help with her charms for killer her husbands.
FolkNotes: On both accused killings she placed something under her then husband's bed.  For her first husband it was an piece of enchanted raw flesh.  For the second it was enchanted powder - the powder supposedly caused him to have problems in is 'privy parts' with burning.
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of bewitching her two husbands to death.  Accused of damaging a man's private parts with a powder.

FolkNotes: Accused of using spells

Charnotes: Mostly quarrelling and threats.  But, Janet Callen, executed for witchcraft in 1659, had lived with Elspeth and supposedly left holes in her hearth stone.  This could have played a part in her developing witch reputation.  Interesting reference to Thomsone being upset at not getting an invitation to a baptism (very much like Sleeping Beauty).
DevilNotes: A delerious man claimed to have seen the Devil as a rat that bit him and that he saw him coming towards him in his yard.
FolkNotes: People were taking thatch from her roof, especially from above her door, to stop her harmful magic from working.  Interestingly, she was described as earnestly offering apples to someone who refused (presumbably out of fear that they were tainted).  Elspeth was suspected of becoming angry at this refusal and caused harm.  She interferred with milk churning, and injured infants of people she quarrelled with.  Neighbours testified that Janet Callen, executed for witchcraft in 1659, had left holes in Elspeth's hearth stone from when she lived there.
DiseaseNotes: She killed a baby after she wasn't invited to the baptism. Quarrels about work, borrowing things, and social slights.

Charnotes: It says that the panel was poinded by her main victim.  She had a lot of threats and curses followed by harm.  And had a solid witchcraft reputaiton.  Also said she used charmes but doesn't specify whether that meant for healing or harming so have not ticked folk healing as there is no evidence that she healed anyone.
DiseaseNotes: Quarrels and threats

Charnotes: Seems like nothing happened with his trial.
FolkNotes: A strange case with lots of strange detail about him trying to get good luck?

Charnotes: Confession of pact.
DevilNotes: Devil in the form of a leper which she confessed she knew to be an evil spirit. In 1662 she confessed that she met 2 men, one was a gross copperfaced man whom she knew was an evil spirit, the other was a well favoured young man.
MeetingNotes: Confessed that she met others at Bute Quay and she fell in the water but the good looking man pulled her out.
DiseaseNotes: confessed several acts of malefice but no details.
CaseNotes: Initally accused in 1662.

DevilNotes: The Devil appeared to him so he could get revenge on a guy for broken promises.  He claimed to have agreed to join the Devil for revenge.  He got the Devil's mark in bed, the devil struck him with a rod, he was then in 'grit extasies and transis', he was carried around to mountains.
MeetingNotes: He confessed to be carried along the water.  Satan stood as in a pulpit and preached sermons, some of which is quoted in the trial text.  They kissed the Devil's behind.  The Devil carried him across the see to the Queen's ship.  They travelled to a ship where they drank good wine and ale then went home.  He sat on the left side of the Devil and was lead about widdershins then kissed is arse.  Satan told them to collect all the cats, he was seen chasing cats.  Accused of dismembering unbaptised babies.  Supposedly a blue flame at the meeting.  See Agnes Sampson for a description fo the North Berwick kirk witches' meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.
FolkNotes: Use of cats to raise winds to sink ships.  They took an object that looked like a fute-ball and cast it in the see to raise 'ane vapour and ane reik' to send the King's ship off.  He blew on a woman's hand to open a lock.  He lit a horse with candles, a magical thing.  He carried the mole's feet around as a talisman so that he wouldn't lack silver.  He walked withershins.  He could predict the future of when and how people would die if he knew their birth day.  Night flying.  Newes From Scotland, describes a foiled love magic attempt.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: The Devil persuaded him to burn down a house in revenge for not keeping a promise.

Charnotes: Seems like nothing happened in her trial.
CaseNotes: She was released and cautioned to stand trial

MeetingNotes: He claimed he could not play the pipes and couldn't have been at a meeting because he has witnesses to say he was drinking ale with a group of people.  Nor did he have a staff, some mention of a brass tobacco pipe.  I assume he was answering charges of being at a witches' meeting and playing the pipes, but we don't have the actual accusations, only his statement.
CaseNotes: His diet was deserted.  The edinburgh porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679 all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.

Charnotes: Indication of neighbourhood dispute, but not enough for a primary characterisation.
DiseaseNotes: quarrels followed by threats.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#596) as being from JC26/38/41 [a source that doesn't exist, probably a typo].  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box number 38 did not find the case.  Larner has this case as processed in some way with an unknown outcome.

DiseaseNotes: This one is all quarrels about work and living, followed by threats and illness and death.

Charnotes: She performed many of her healing rituals on holy days.
FolkNotes: Her case is all about healing.  She seemed to specialise in healing children and infants.  She did many of her cures on the Sabbath and other holy days.  Diagnosed bewitchment.  A transcription of some of her case is in Larner et al.'s Sourcebook, p. 269.  Some of her cures invovled moving the sick child around and putting it in a cradle.  She supposedly left her 'witchcraft' on the hearth stone of her former house.  The next family that moved in suffered losses to their cattle.  She caused a cow to be put through a circle of green yarn for a cure.
DiseaseNotes: She cured cows and children.  Also killed a cow.

Charnotes: The minimal indication given in the circuit court books is that she was accused of one count of a fallout, followed by threats followed by disease.  But not enough to base a whole charactarisation on.
DiseaseNotes: Just one item described

CaseNotes: some women from Stranraer presbytery

Charnotes: They supposedly consulted four witches after a dispute as to a davoch of land.
CaseNotes: Process notes 12 July 1590 state that he and his wife were charged with consulting witches.

Charnotes: This case is all about quarrels, threats and misfortune.
FolkNotes: A boy had a nightmare that she was gripping him and he woke up on the floor in pain.  She asked for someone's health on her knees and the person recovered.
DiseaseNotes: Angry because a man killed her dog after it had killed his lambs. Went away murmering after refused fodder and straw.  Dispute over the price of the produce from a croft. Quarrel and threats with the miller. Son refused a herding job.
CaseNotes: This group was first processed in 1671 and 1672.  Not sure what happened to reopen things again in 1679 with the addition of Margaret Fleming.
This group was first processed in 1671 and 1672.  Not sure what happened to reopen things again in 1679 with the addition of Margaret Fleming.

DevilNotes: She turned to the Devil in despair of her poverty.  The devil always asked if she wanted revenge of anyone.  Got her devil's mark in a privy place, and it hurt until 'the devil lay with her' then the pain was eased.
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.

DevilNotes: For sex, she cast her face down to the ground and the devil used her 'after the maner of a beast'.  Her spirit was named Laurie Moir
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.

DevilNotes: She owned a spirit that appeared to her as her spirit - his name was Peter Drysdale.
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.
There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet Hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.
DiseaseNotes: got a white powder from the Devil to poison her brother.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Wanted revenge on her brother for getting more of her father's estate after his death.
DefenseNotes: professed her willingness to die for her sin

Charnotes: Very poor handwritting, it was difficult to tell what was going on in this case.
FolkNotes: Something about a baptism and meeting a woman but the handwritting it terrible.  I think there is mention of a serk.  She took the sark to
DiseaseNotes: I think she is healing bairns, the handwritting is terrible.  Or else she is part of the murder of two infants with Meg Dow and a drink.

DevilNotes: She denied having sex with the Devil, she did not get a Devil's mark and the Devil did not give her a new name.
MeetingNotes: she danced and made mirth
She supposedly carried her neice out to the fields to give her over to the Devil.

DevilNotes: She confessed that the Devil appeared to her after a fall out with her daughter offering her revenge, she agreed.
Devil drank to her and she drank to him
DefenseNotes: She doesn't wish to live because she has kept up with the sacraments and church going the whole time she was a witch.

DevilNotes: He kissed her and he had no breath (the man in green clothes).  She denied to any harm
MeetingNotes: accused of being at a meeting by another accused witch.  She denied the cows burn meeting.
DiseaseNotes: Marion Veitch (c/egd/694) said she helped kill her grandson.

Charnotes: It is difficult to characterise this case as there is no evidence of accusations related to witchcraft. The concerns of the presbytery relate more to his 'scandalous carriage' such as his affair with his servant, non-attendance at kirk, lack of visiting of his parishioners and pilfering of the poor fund rather than practising witchcraft or magic.  He was indicted for witchcraft with a group in the circuit court.
CaseNotes: he was indicted for witchcraft on 8

MeetingNotes: Devil's meeting described by Margaret Dods
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).

Charnotes: Accused by another witch of trying ot kill her own daughter.

Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Others said he met the man as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the North Berwick meeting. Said to have been at the meeting at the kirk in North Berwick where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Said by others to have been involved in rituals using corpse and corpse powder and attended rituals at Halloween.
CaseNotes: There is a Johne Makgill from Garvald mentioned in Haddington Presbytery records as a suspect in 12/6/1588 but not clear if it is the same person. No further details,

Charnotes: A local panic?
CaseNotes: named with 26 others

DevilNotes: While she was sleeping, Sarah Cranston woke her and told her that 'it behoved her to speak with a gentleman', he was a black man who took her in his arms and kissed her.  She said that Marion Veitch gave her child of one year to the Devil.
MeetingNotes: accused of being at two meetings by another accused witch.  She said that Sarah Cranston rode a horse to death from riding to and from meetings.

DevilNotes: Accused generally of having entered into a pact with the Devil, and all the rest.  But no record of the specific charges against her
She described the Devil as an Englishman with the last name Webb, who cured diseases gave her a drink to make her fertile.  She later knew he was the Devil.
DiseaseNotes: She was cured by a known healer

MeetingNotes: accused of being at three meetings by another accused witch.  The meetings were at Kirk Bridge, ward haugh and corsehill.

DevilNotes: she fell asleept at Keith Banks Falls and Marion Veatch 'in bodily likeness' came to her.
MeetingNotes: accused of being at three meetings by another accused witch.
FolkNotes: Marion Veatch appeared to her 'in bodily likeness'  in her sleep.

CaseNotes: Listed in presbytery with others accused of witchcraft.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick hunt, that revovled around witchcraft and treason.  She was definitely a folk healer who got mixed up in the treason trials.  She implicated 59 people for witchcraft.  She was a folk healer who healed very high status people.
DevilNotes: Devil came to her after her husband died, she was moved by poverty and the chance for revenge.  At the time she thought the Devil's mark was a hurt she received from one of her children who was in bed with her.  In order to heal she called the Devil by the name of 'Elva' and he came as a dog.  The Devil carried a staff.  She confessed to these things in front of King James VI.  She denied that the spirits she met were the Devil.
MeetingNotes: One of the meetings was like a party at sea with good wine and ale.  She travelled over the water in a boat like a chimney and the Devil went before them in a ruk of hay.  They baptised a cat.  Witches meeting with nine people.  She described 11 separate witches meetings.  North Berwick meeting was a classic description of a black mass.  First there was dancing. The women payed homage, then the men.  The men walked withershins 9 times, the women 6 tymes.  Fean was the right hand man, Johnne Gray-meil guarded the door.  There were prayers, black candles and a whole service.  There were supposedly 6 men to 94 women at the meeting.  She also denied all the North Berwick stuff in a mega-confession.  Then later in the confession she talked about the North Berwick stuff (was she tortured?)
FolkNotes: Predicted someone's death.  She said the Devil was responsible for storms around Michaelmas and that they would continue.  Learned her healing from her father.  Gripping to cure.  She did lots of rituals with cats, passing them around and combining them with joints (dead people's).  They cast live cats into the sea, the cats swam out again.  Did a version of the Lord's Prayer, Ave Marias.  She was paid to heal very high status people (Lords, lairds, and their wives) from a large territory.  She prescribed an egg dipped in vinager, and one dipped in white wine, rubbed a patient with Aqua vitea.  Healed someone on Halloween.  She blessed a ring.
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of failing to heal many times.  Her range in healing was large, North Berwick, Direlton, Preston, Dalkeith.  She was hired by rich and poor people for healing.  She was paid for her services.  She helped ease the pain of childbirth.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Part of the witches' crew that wanted to destroy King James VI and Queen Ann of Denmark.  The Devil bad them party on a ship, but the mariners could not see them, the Devil raised wind and rocked the boat.  She confessed that she quarreled with J. Straton
CaseNotes: A copy of her confession was sent from Bowes to Burghley, in it he said that she confessed to 58 out of the 102 items in her dittay.  She died penitent and praying to God for her salvation.
