DevilNotes: She went to collect a debt from Elizabeth Scotland and was chased by a black thing.  The Devil claimed to be a wealthy man who had lived in Linlithgow and promised to lend her 100 merks, which he failed to do.  The Devil shook hands with her and her hand was sore.
CaseNotes: The project did not check Larner's reference to this case in a printed secondary source as part of the research. The unchecked secondary source indicates a date of 10/5/1680 - possibly an execution?

DevilNotes: First he kissed her, he didn't lay with her immediately because she was pregnant.  He lay with her after she was kirked (i.e. lying in period).  He rebaptised her and three others by a 'waff' of his hand across their faces.  Helen Laying and the Devil laid hands on her for the renunciation of her baptism.
MeetingNotes: Lots of witches and a flaming fire 'Devil gave them a kind of sacrament and preached among them and blasphemed God'.
FolkNotes: While in the shape of bees she and Marion Veitch carried the poison used to kill Veitch's grandson in their 'cleuchis, wings and mouth'.  She claimed that Helen Laying (her master) kept her from church and had her carry water from a well instead.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).  Helped Kill the grandson of Marion Veitch (c/egd/694).

DevilNotes: Denies having a new name, denies sex with the devil, denies that she did anything wrong.  She was obviously questioned about these things!
MeetingNotes: Devil's meetings described by Margaret Dods, Helen confessed to meeting the devil in her yard and as ward burnes.  She denied bringing anyone else to meetings.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).  Accused of killing her husband, William Laying.  She denies being guily of any malefice.
DefenseNotes: Denies being guilty of malefice

DevilNotes: She could only manage to put her hand as low as her knee for the 'head and foot'.  His nature was cold and he had no breath.
Devil required her to destroy her nieghbours but she couldn't do it because God woulnd't allow it.  Her aunt, Marioun Veitch carried her to the fields to meet the Devil.
FolkNotes: She left her body at the kirk in Pencaitland when she went out as a corbie.
DiseaseNotes: confessed to killing her grandson at the Devil's request.

Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: She confessed that she wasn't fast enough in renouncing her baptism and that the Devil dragged her by her coat and broke the band.  She said she was the Devil's 'slave', he struck her and abused her, she tried many times to confess her sins to a minister, but the Devil wouldn't let her.

Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: She was promised by Sara Crantoun that the Devil would make her well liked by women for her career as a midwife.  Sara also promised her a 'cheise', but she never got it.  She said that it was 'greed of her imployment that engaded her to the devillis service'.

Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: At first the Devil just embraced her.  Later at Heriot Back, 'the devill tempted her to uncleannes and hade carnall copulation with her and that he wes all as cold as ire.'
DiseaseNotes: She killed animals  by riding them to death

Charnotes: She was accused of killing two high ranking men with image magic.
FolkNotes: She was accused of making  a wax and clay images and putting them over a fire to kill two high ranking men (Lord Cochran and Hammilton)
CaseNotes: listed as a fugitive from dumbarton, but the document clearly states she is from Stirlingshire.  Ordered to appear in Edinburgh on 5/1/1680.
certain persons from Humbie and Keithmarschall to be executed.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.
The clothes Bessie supposedly wore to a meeting were described by Elizabeth Scotland - Red coat, black caille with a hood on her head, pearling on her face and a plaid about her shoulders.

DevilNotes: He promised her pearls and jewels which he showed to her.  At first she refused to have sex with him because of her husband.  She exchanged words with the Devil 'I am thyne and thow art mine.'  He appeared in her shop and dissapeared when people came in.
Devil appeared at a dam where a woman had killed herself.  He told her he would be a good husband to her.
MeetingNotes: Meeting at the links after the last harvest.  She described the clothes Bessie Gibb's clothing wore to the meeting and said there were 18 people there.  She went to the meeting on horseback.

Charnotes: Described as a charmer of cows, previously banished.

DevilNotes: Promised her gold money and great riches.
MeetingNotes: dance and be merry

CaseNotes: I could not find this source in the NAS, and I could not find anyone else who knows what it is.  Therefore, I can not put any information about Robertson in this records.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: planning meeting to getQueen Anne's ship on its way to Scotland.

Charnotes: He did not show up in the processes from 1697, but was said to have been denounced at that time.  He was denounced by Margaret Laird and girl claiming to be possessed.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: She was named by Margaret Murdoch for tormenting her. See Agnes Supp for a description of the torment/possession.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: He was told another child that he was a warlock and that his mother was a witch.  He was accused of tormenting a boy and a possessed girl.  He was subjected to the water test (possibly by other children?) and failed  - he did not sink.  They did the test on another boy who sank.
DevilNotes: His mother told him to do the head and foot to give himself over to the devil.  The Devil took him away with him.
CaseNotes: Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: She was a poor woman who seemed to move around a lot.  She was denounced by her son (sort of) when he told other kids that he was a witch and that so was his mother.  She was accused of tormenting Margaret Laird one two girls claiming possession in 1699.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possession.
DevilNotes: Accused by her son of making him join the Devil (see c/egd/735) for details of his case.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations.

Charnotes: She seems to have been a troublesome woman, asking for charity and doing lots of cursing and offensive gestures.  Lots of muttering after refused charity.  She begging at people's homes and at an Abbey in Paisley.  Accused of causing an undescribed tormenting.
FolkNotes: She was offered a dollar for appeasement.  Lots of muttering and curses.
DiseaseNotes: mostly curses and illnesses.  She cursed someone at a like-wake.  She stuck her tongue out after making curses.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Just says that she had a devil's mark, nothing more.
CaseNotes: Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: She was originally denounced after a problem at the mill.  But she was denounced by Margaret Laird one of the possessed girls from the 1699 paisley group.  I think she was a trouble maker with a reputation for harmful magic who got swept into a possession prosecution.  The main accusation was causing harm after refusal of alms or charity.  She supposed denounced quite a few others.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: Used a 'charme' meaning an object to cure someone.
DiseaseNotes: turned blood to milk, interfered with butter.  Damaged a mill because of refusal of alms.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: part of the planning of the conspiracy to sink Queen Anne's ships on the way  from Denmark.  Part of North Berwick witches.
FolkNotes: tied four joints from a dead man to the feet of a cat, cast it into the sea, the cat swam back.  All this to make wind.

Charnotes: Definitely about quarrelling and cursing followed by magical harm. But she seems to have been swept into the the possession cases of 1699 in Renfrewshire.  Supposedly the tormentor of Margaret Laird and Christian Shaw.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
DevilNotes: Was pricked for the mark.
DiseaseNotes: good description of the curse accompanied by clapping.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: she was accused of causing tormentings of Margaret Laird and of stealing milk with sympathetic magic, as well as of cursing followed by harm.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: Very interesting description of a sympathetic magic ritual.  She was accused of holding a leather strap as if she were milking a cow.  This action supposedly magically took the cows milk from her neighbour, thereby increasing her output and destroying her neighbours milk/dairy output.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!  The second arrest, was about the possession of two girls Margaret Laird and Margaret Murdoch Laird was unable to eat or drink but there are no details about whether there was some personal dispute involved.  The usual possession symptoms - spitting pins, contortions, pain, bite marks, and calling out names of tormentors.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
DiseaseNotes: accused of killing a child.  Main accusation was possession.
CaseNotes: She was released from prison due to pregnancy.  She was confined to Edinburgh by the Privy Council on 6 September 1698 to answer to them any time before 15 November 1698 for accusations of witchcraft.  She seems to have been charged again in 1699 and then the diet was deserted in 1700.  This is the same general trajectory as Annabel Reid (c/la/2971)  Her husband's bond of caution survives - 20/5/1699.  Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Was indicted with others accused of tormenting children.  But he seems to be a straightforward failed healer who got caught up in the 1699 prosecutions.
FolkNotes: Used hair as a charm to cure.  The objects were used to heal. Used rowan tree belt wrapped nine times to cure ?frigidity. Used nail clippings, eye brow hair and hairs from the crown of the head and half a penny wrapped in cloth. Told witness to sow some milk in with his corn on Beltane day. Told another man to boil a stirck (young cow) and burn the rest of the bones to ashes and then bury them. Dougall said this would cure the sturdie (scrappie) disease in his beasts.
DiseaseNotes: He was noted as unsuccessful at healing a girl, seemed to be better at healing animals. Used charms to heal frigidity and convulsions. Hair, money and nails were left so whoever found them would get the disease and remove it from the first person.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Claimed he had taught a man how to get part of another man's fishing.
CaseNotes: He was accused with others who were denounced by tormented girls, but he appears to have been a healer (called a charmer in the record).  Connected with the Margaret Murdoch cases.

Charnotes: Delated by Margaret Murdoch for causing her tormenting.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: accused of doing a charme with a frog at the threshhold.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Was delated by Margaret Murdoch for tormenting her and troubling her with 'evil spirits'.  Gilmore had a good reputation till then, but her mother was reputed a witch.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: was accused of using a frog at the threshold for a charm.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: She was mostly accused of causing the tormenting/possession of Margaret Murdoch after Murdoch stole from Janet.  She was also accused of trying to get Murdoch to give herself over the devil, by signing a piece of paper and by doing the head and foot.  See Agnes Supp for description of torment.
DevilNotes: Tried to get someone to do the head and foot.
FolkNotes: She was blamed for a charme involving a frog at the threshhold.  She also advised someone to wade into the Clyde.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Accused of tormenting Margaret Murdoch and of appearing to a guy in his bed chamber with Marion Ure and Margaret Duncan.  See Agnes Supp for description of the possesion.
FolkNotes: appeared as an apparition to a guy in his bed chamber with 2 other witches the three also appeared as animals - a sow, a cat and an ape.
CaseNotes: Her husband's bond of caution for her survives - 1699.  Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of Govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Part of the planning to raise the storm for the North Berwick sinking of King's ships.

Charnotes: She was accused of tormenting Margaret murdoch and of appearing in a guy's bed chamber with Margaret Duncan and Jannet Gentleman.  See Agnes Supp for description of the possesion.
FolkNotes: Danced as an apparition with 2 others in a guys bed chamber - they also appeared as a sow, a cat and an ape.
DiseaseNotes: She spoke threatening words to a man and later appeared in his bed chamber
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Charnotes: Indicted for using spells and enchantments and for corresponding with the Devil.  I think this could be refused charity because there is a mention of pain in her bowels when she asked for food.
DevilNotes: corresponding with the devil
DiseaseNotes: wronged several of her neighbours cattle.  Some evidence of quarrels and threats. She was refused entertainment (i.e. food).

Charnotes: mention of using curses and enchantments against her neighbours.  And also for 'corresponding' with the Devil.

DiseaseNotes: She was accused of murder using witchcraft.
CaseNotes: Don't know what happened in terms of a trial so I have not ticked any type of trial process.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: meeting to arrange the conspiracty to stall the Queen's ship on its return from Denmark.  They were told to make storms on the same day and time

DiseaseNotes: accused of taking away men's members

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case as being from JC17/1 a fugitive list.  The Survey of Scottish Witchcraft did not include this source as part of its remit.  Larner has this case as being processed with an unknown outcome.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: the meeting at sea was like a party with good wine and ale.  See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.

DiseaseNotes: Malefices

Charnotes: she was delated by other witches, not specified in the record.  Most of the accusations seem relate to quarrels followed by harm, but the evidence is sketchy.
DevilNotes: delated by witches but doesn't say who.
FolkNotes: Someone asked for their health for God's sake.  She diagnosed Colic for her daughter.
DiseaseNotes: proposed marriage for her daughter, refused, revenge. Neighbour refused to reciprocate ale round, curses, illness. Man refused to cart her herring, threats, illness. Refusal to pay a fee to her daughter, threats, illness.

Charnotes: indicted for consulting with witches, charmers and such as have familiar spirites particularly the dumb man in the correction house of Edinburgh in October 1678.  He was not charged with having his own familiar spirits.
CaseNotes: diet was deserted

Charnotes: Definitely neighbourhood dispute, lots of quarreling over work, animals, ale purchases, stolen aqua vitae fire, rent collection.  She was accused of flyting.  She threatened a Kirk searcher who found her not at church on a Sunday.  Another accused witch had been hired by her neighbours to stop her and in the process she implicated Sawer for witchcraft.  She was denounced by Helen Gavin.  She denied it all!
FolkNotes: horses that died on lammas were blamed on her.  A woman saw four cats dancing 'as it weir dancing the reill dance', the cats went to Jannet's house.  Jannett also accused a woman of stealing an ingle [fire] from the aqua vitae pot, the supposed thief suffered great pain and boils.  I think this was a counter-strategy tried on Jannett.  A man who was going to report her to the session for missing church on a Sunday got ill on the Monday and just before his death saw her with 'a devil out of hell'.
DiseaseNotes: she was mentioned as taking away a woman's milk, bewitching people and animals, and killing a bairn.  Quarrelling over stables, over payment to her son, rent collection, theft.  She was summond to the Kirk session for stealing wort and ale.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: The Ship of Balfast came to Ayr for takell (it was bound for Barbados), she supposedly raised a storm to destroy it.  Jannett was seen lying within the sea mark with her mouth up, sucking the air 'lyk ane adder'.
CaseNotes: Her execution was described in a letter of Colonel Robert Sawrey, dated 26 April 1658.  He described her speech in which she denied all witchcraft and confessed to her wicked life and made exhortations to the living.  The speech is used in the letter to show that Ayr is hunting witches.  We already knew this from the many trial records we have.

Charnotes: looks like a neighbourhood dispute one, but we don't have the dittay, just the witnesses responses to the dittay.  That does not give us enough information to tell for sure.
DiseaseNotes: accused of getting magical revenge for harm done to her family.

Charnotes: No specific details about Miller but according to Dumfries presbytery records it appears she was noted as a 'witch woman' but seems to have given advice about folk healing.  Her draft dittay shows that she was a recognised healer who travelled far and wide.  Her witchcraft reputation seems to have come from failed healing attempts and because she told people to keep her cures from the ministers.  Lots of fairry stuff.  The church and others might have been threatened by her advice to her patients to keep her cures a secret.  This may have lead people to believe that what she was doing was wrong?
DevilNotes: Says she convenit [convened] with the Devil in her dream.  She confessed to having a familiar, but it was not described as an an animal and it could have been a familiar spirit?  She claimed that the Devil gave her power to heal.  After her husband, [died?] she worried about her livelihood that is when the Devil came to her.  The Devil allowed her to hear the threatenings of other witches and see the diseases at great distance.
FolkNotes: Foxtree leaves (foxglove) used to cure sickness. The consulter was told to take her mother to a certain place, wash her and use foxtree leaves, and leave the sickness at the place where she got it.  She diagnosed an illness as possibly related to the fairries having taken his tongue, if this was true she could be no help to him.  But he should try foxtree leaves and S. running water.  She gripped a child and told them to keep it close and away from the minister.  Diagnosed a child with 'Ferrie blast'.  She did a cure where the victim had to sit between three fires.  A ritual with smoke and fire to get a man out of a witch's grip.  Again told to keep it close especially from the minister.  Advised to keep the bible near for a cure for distempter.  She said a man became ill after digging up a thorn tree.  She diagnosed bewitchings as caused by Kirkcudbright and Dumfries witches (told the victims to get 3 stopings of straw from the witches' roof and burn them).
DiseaseNotes: She denied doing any malefice, but said she could 'take off' diseases (i.e. cure). Healing ritual recorded in Dumfries presbytery records. She advised taking sick person to the place they got illness and carry out ritual in order to cure them.

Charnotes: Looks like a neighbourhood dispute.  She also complained to the minister of slander and when he didn't take her seriously she cursed him and he got ill.  But for some reason, and despite lots of witness depositions, she was found not guilty.  Perhaps it is because those same witness did not offer compelling testimony during the trial?
DevilNotes: She denied both of them, but they were mentioned in the trial record so I decided to list them here.
FolkNotes: Marione stole coal from a woman's hearth fire.  This seems to have been related to a bewitchment.  'A wife' told the women from whom Marion stole coal that this was not good and it resulted in a flyting incident between the two.  At an earlier point I think it was unclear which flyter was the 'witch'.  After the flyting the other woman woke up with a paddock [a toad] under her clothes and then her best cow died.
DiseaseNotes: lots of cursing and fallouts followed by malefice.  She quarreled about corn. Other people's cattle eat her corn and she sent her animals to eat theirs.  Flyting.  Quarrels and curses over a borrowed horse.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: She stole coal from a someone's hearth fire.
CaseNotes: Listed as a Dumfries delinquent to be cited to appear in the tolbooth for 2/4/1659.  Was she going to be tried again?

Charnotes: definitely seems to be neighbourhood dispute and she seems to have been in trouble before for sleeping with an English soldier and she was fined 2 dollars by the bailies of Ayr for something.
DevilNotes: mention of the Devil but nothing specific
DiseaseNotes: was angry after being refused malt. Quarrels about daily tasks and after having been caught sleeping with an English soldier. Hatred of bailie of Ayr for fining her 2 dollars. Man refused to carry her malt.

Charnotes: The circuit court record is just witness commentary on their deposition.  No clear indication of what the dittay said or what she was charged with.  Witness depositions mentioned some healingn activities, but this was more in the range of people asking her to remove illness that they believed she had caused (i.e. asking for removal of bewitchment).  She does not appear to have been a charmer.  The main problem seems to have been quarrelling, cursing and illness - i.e. neighbourhood dispute.
DevilNotes: A description of a dog and hare of the accused going out to some cow.  The handwriting is difficult, hard to tell exactly what was happening, but could be a case of familiars.  The witness depositions allege a hare that was in her house and followed people after quarrels.
FolkNotes: After she gave birth she caused the midwife to use supersticious rites, used salt for the baptism, instructed eveyone to walk home speechless from the baptism, and burn hindberry leaves around the child.
DiseaseNotes: She also prayed for healing, but it seemed to fail quite a lot.  She was denied peats after a healing attempt failed. Her dittay is all about quarrels and threats, specifically about her lambs stealing grain and milk, and cow trouble.  Malicious prayers

MeetingNotes: Marioun Chatto described as the principle of the meetings.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Said by Napier and Sampson that she met the devil as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: Others claimed that she was part of the planning in the conspiracy to sink James VI ships on the way back from Denmark.  See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the meeting at the kirk in North Berwick and at the saltpans. A trump was played at these.
FolkNotes: Others said she was involved in rituals with corpse, corpse powder and a cat and attended meetings at Halloween.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Others claimed that she was involved in rituals to sink the royal ships by raising winds and storms.

Charnotes: The record in the circuit court documents is just comments from witnesses about their depositions and the dittay.  Not very clear.  Witness depositions have both healing and dispute elements.  I decided on dispute because there seems to be more description of malefice rather than curing.
FolkNotes: She put a bannock in the wall to protect the cows.  Cured with a prayer and I think a fish?
DiseaseNotes: argument re: wages for a wright, curses, her beasts ate a man's seed stock so he kept her from the brewing water well (it filled with toads), injured the bailie after he poined her goods.
CaseNotes: We think this is the same person as C/EGD/2334.

Charnotes: The record is just witness comments on their depositions, very patchy.  She supposedly asked to borrow meal and was refused followed by cursing and malefice.  I am not ticking Refused charity, because I think it was a request between equals and the word 'borrow' was specifically used.  Implying that this was not 'charity'.  Although she was called a 'pyker and a theif' I think this was slander, not an accurate description of her status. JC26 documents confirm definate neighbourhood disputes!
DevilNotes: She was seen with a black boy who was black all over but not specified as the Devil or supernatural in any way.
FolkNotes: Withershins.  She had a quarrel with a man who accused her of leaving a black cleise and three blue yearns under his milking cow (a charm).  A man who was to confiscate their things found a black toad in his bed and died.
DiseaseNotes: Flyting, grazing disputes (removal of kercheif), ale, borrowed meal.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: a man refused to marry her daughter and married another, so the bride died.
CaseNotes: Possibly same person as Janet McGoane, e/egd/2335.

Charnotes: The record is comments from people who witnessed her confession, very patchy.  She mentioned going away with the Fferrie, and contact with the Devil.  From what we have in the witness depositions she confessed to demonic elements then retracted.  She was described as 'one demented' so I think the main impetus behind her case was all the devil stuff.
DevilNotes: The devil drank to her.  She said the Devil came to her in prison and said he could strangle her like he did for Helen Harris.  She claimed that no one else could see the devil in the tolbooth because he had rubbed something in her eyes.
MeetingNotes: Says she hosted witches within the walls of ??? Dundrenan.
FolkNotes: She confessed to being away with the Fferrie.  Had a great meeting with the not earthen folkis and not earthly talkis.  They had a fire and dancing and myrth.  When asked how she knew them she said they were 'fairer and beltin busked [beltane bound] and that they spak with ane eldridge voyce' [elvish voice].  She said the Devil came to her in prison and said he could strangle her like he did for Helen Harris.  She claimed that no one else could see the devil in the tolbooth because he had rubbed something in her eyes.

Charnotes: The circuit court docs have bad handwriting and is just ratification of witness statements.  Found a second record of witness statements that shows that the main things here were disputes, curses and failed healing attempts.  One oblique mention of not being paid for healing.  The dittay from the Dumfries dittay roll is all quarrels and curses, no healing.  Therefore I decided to put Neighbourhood dispute as the primary.
DevilNotes: She was seen with a tall, black, ugly man.
FolkNotes: Denounced by Jonet Miller when she diagnosed an illness as being caused by Jannet Corsan after a quarrel and curse.
DiseaseNotes: there was mention that she cured for pay.  Quarrel about losing a croft, about refusal of borrowing, inheritance dispute (she wanted a pot and crook), curse with courch removal.  Dispute over borrowed cradle.

Charnotes: The circuit record is just people ratifying their witness depositions.  Very little information about what the charges actually were.  The dittay roll has more detail, enough to assign a primary of Neighbourhood dispute.  Plenty of good detail.
FolkNotes: Appeasement offered to her of milk and bread.  This means that people were trying to make up with her so that she would no longer feel malice towards them and would desist in magically harming them.
DiseaseNotes: Cursing for God's malediction on her knees. Quarrels over kale, stolen faggot, social insults, and purchases of wool and flesh.

Charnotes: Seems to be all about curses followed by harm, but  difficult to tell from the circuit court records, because the record is just witness ratifications of their depositions. The witness deposition is mostly people ratifying their testimony - not a lot of detail.  Dittay has lots of details about quarrels, curses, and illness.
FolkNotes: Poured cows milk into Jennat's yard to heal a cow.  Janet Miller diagnosed her as the cause of someone's illness told her to get 3 stoppings of Straw from Jennat's roof and burn them.  So she was the subject of counter-magic, that means that her neighbours thought she was using harmful magic on people.
DiseaseNotes: Also caused someone to fall into a trance. Curse after getting kicked out of her house. Cow's milk.  Threats re: bleaching linen, cow in the corn (courch removal). Injured woman for marrying the man Jennat wanted.

MeetingNotes: Marioun Chatto described as the principle of the meetings.

Charnotes: Seems to be all about cursing and scolding followed by disease, but impossible to say for certain because the record in the Circuit Court is just witness ratifications of their depositions in court.  Have more detail in the JC26 documents, which do show a strong neighbourhood dispute theme.  She was accused by her brother-in-law after her husband's death when she wanted liferent, it seems their was also a dispute about her inheritance.
DiseaseNotes: This one seems to be all about cursing and scolding followed by disease.  Her sister and brother-in-law died, childbirth problems. She killed her eldest in favour of her next son. Took a woman's milk.  Killed with bitter imprecations. Flyting
CaseNotes: There was a dispute over her terce, she wanted the liferent of her dead husband's land and the half mark of her brother in law.  It was her brother who accused her of witchcraft!  She was also accused of causing harm to a man who had gotten her sister pregnant and then married another.

Charnotes: Too little to even think about ticking secondary characteristics!  Very little information and very bad handwritting.  The court book is better, but still not enough detail.
DevilNotes: Described her cat going before the cow.
MeetingNotes: Supposedly against the minister's wife
FolkNotes: Mention of her cat always being around a sick child, when they killed the cat the child recovered.  Someone found half burnt thorns at her heathstone.  Tait asked for a bannock and then asked for more and was refused because the woman didn't want to give her more than one thing at a time so as to prevent the 'witch' from having power over her.
DiseaseNotes: She prayed to God for someone to recover and they did.  This is not folk healing but removal of bewtichment.  Threats and illness.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: A man refused to kiss her and he became ill.

FolkNotes: She was accused of healing and casting rats and other animals and causing other beasts to suddenly die. [In the circuit court books this was described only as charming, in the Aberdeen Roll she was charged with witchcraft and charming - shows the fuzzy distinction between the two.]
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of healing, but not sure if it was animals or people.

CaseNotes: execution of certain persons from Tranent.

MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See Napier (c/egd/103) for description of other meeting. They said she was at meetings at the shore and at the kirk in North Berwick, where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Detailed description by others of how she was supposedly involved in preparation for North Berwick meeting. Said to have used corpse, corpse powder, snake skin, toad, urine and wax/clay images in rituals. Also meetings at Halloween.

She was accused of healing and casting rats and other animals and causing other beasts to suddenly die. [In the circuit court books this was described only as charming, in the Aberdeen Roll she was charged with witchcraft and charming - shows the fuzzy distinction between the two.]
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of healing, but not sure if it was animals or humans.

Charnotes: Just accused of killing a man with an enchanted drink, and of quarreling and cursing.
DiseaseNotes: accused of killing a man with an enchanted drink.  Anger after a discord behind her malefice.

Charnotes: says nothing
Seems that nothing happened with her trial.
CaseNotes: First processed in 1662, she was released by the Privy Council, then called up in front of the circuit court in 24/5/1671, nothing happened.  Then she was on a list of fugitives on a Porteous Roll of dittay delinquents.

Charnotes: Nothing seems to have happened with her case.  Her diet was deserted in 1679.
CaseNotes: The court left her case hanging in 1671, the diet was deserted in 1679.

Charnotes: seems like nothing much happened with her case
seems that nothing happened with his trial.
nothing seems to have happened with her trial.

indicted for consulting with witches, charmers and such as have familiar spirites particularly the dumb man in the correction house of Edinburgh in October 1678.  He was not charged with having familiar spirits himself.
CaseNotes: diet was deserted

Charnotes: He was indicted for consulting with witches and such as have familiar spirits, not with having his own familiar spirit.
accused of taking away a man's sight and hearing
DiseaseNotes: accused of taking away a man's sight and hearing.
CaseNotes: The edinburgh porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679 all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.

CaseNotes: Christian, along with Agnes Kelly  (c/egd/1762) and her servant M. Anderson (c/egd/1761), were pressured to denounce Elspeth Chousley (c/egd/822) who was extrajudicially beaten and arrested for witchcraft.

Her community attempted to extrajudicially arrest and investigate her for witchcraft.  Her tormentors were charged with Hamsucken, robery, wrong imprisonment, and hurting subjects.  In June of July 1677 a group of people broke into her house, took things and broke things.  They kept her in prison and hired a pricker.  They also tortured three other witches and pressured them to denounce her.  She paid to get out of prison and was released.  Then in June or July of 1678 the group assaulted her again - they broke her doors and windows and went at her with swords and pistols.  The baillie was drunk when this happened.  Five people testified to these events.

Charnotes: Accused of malefices against a smith.
MeetingNotes: Confessed that she met other witches in the Loan. In another entry another woman, Jean Durkie, told the presbytery that she had gone to Nicolas Lauson and asked her to make her a witch.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing a boy to take fits.
CaseNotes: Was one of a group of women who were accused ot tormenting a local lad, Patick Morton.  This is another possession case.  A group of seven people were charged with causing the tormenting of Patrick Morton, the sixteen year old son of a smith in Pittenweem.  The town officials cite the precedent of 'Bargarrans daughter in the west' when applying for a commission for trial.  The Privy Council appointed Her Majesty's Advocate, Sir James Stewart to prosecute the cases and the Privy Council said they would pay for it from the treasury.

Charnotes: accused of using malefices on a smith.
DevilNotes: Denied she made pact but did say she had gone with the devil and that she had renounced her baptism. Said the devil could change shape.
MeetingNotes: Said she saw the devil on Ceres moor.
FolkNotes: Denied that she had used a wax image but said she had used water and coals to harm Morton.
CaseNotes: One of a group of women accused of tormenting a young lad, Patrick Morton.  This is another possession case.  A group of seven people were charged with causing the tormenting of Patrick Morton, the sixteen year old son of a smith in Pittenweem.  The town officials cite the precedent of 'Bargarrans daughter in the west' when applying for a commission for trial.  The Privy Council appointed Her Majesty's Advocate, Sir James Stewart to prosecute the cases and the Privy Council said they would pay for it from the treasury.
Larner has this case in her Privy Council section.
justice courts held by the Earl of Angus in Jedburgh.

The Bailies tried to instigate new charges and to create a new trial, but failed.  Said she took caution in the books of adjournal for her appearance at the next circuit court?  Didn't find any evidence in the circuit court records.

CaseNotes: he and Hew Methven denounced as rebels for not answering their charges.  I am not sure if they were being summond for a trial or not, therefore I have not indicated  trial process.

He was denounced with George Methven as a rebel for not appearing when summond by the Privy Council. I am not sure if they were being summond for a trial or not, therefore I have not indicated  trial process.
charges were brought against her first in 1606, she was granted a continuance for her trial due to pregnancy, her case was not resumed untill 1624.

Charnotes: This person along with 6 others was charged with using witchcraft, consulting witches, and poisoning to kill Johnne and Alexander Erskine sons to the late David Erskin in Logy.  I suspect this is a dynastic struggle, especially since the only listed commissioner for this group trial was Johnne Erskine, 7th Earl of Mar.  But not enough evidence to use the characterisation boxes.

mostly charming with shirts (sarks).  Could cure 'the waff of ane ill wind or foirspeiking'.  This would be equivalent to removing a bewitchment or a fairy illness.  She would be the kind of person someone would go to if they thought a witch was damaging them.
CaseNotes: in 1617 she was called up to the kirk session for charming and admonished.  She didn't stop, and was questioned by the presbytery in 1621.

Recorded in the PC as being held in tolbooth under suspicion of 'using of charmes'.  She was seems to have been a healer who received her power from fairies.  Although she denied being a healer.
DevilNotes: The grey bearded man told her that John Roch's child would die.
FolkNotes: She confessed to using special water.  She washed a sick child and asked for healing in the name of the father, son and holy ghost.  Then cast the bairns shirt in the burn.  She was nearly able to transfer the disease, but she spilt some water and it didn't work.  She was asked if she met fairies, she answered yes, 10 years prior.  She claimed that she stayed in a fairy hill for three days -Thursday till Sunday.  Met with a man with a grey beard.  She made 3 cakes, out of 9 handfuls of meal gotten from 9 different women.  She collected well water for healing. Sharg - tiny ill-thriving creature, probably a changeling.
DiseaseNotes: She was asked if she had skill of curing.  She said no.  Fortold the death of a child.  She was caught stealing bere, and said threatening words.  Her powers came from the fairy.

FolkNotes: She had 'ane great bag lyk ane fwynes bledder' [A great bag like a faune's bladder] on her lap which she claimed was her guts which a woman had trampled out with her knees.  [Is this some reference to the shamanistic removal of organs?]  She seems to imply that she was being bewitched and was trying to find the witch who was plagueing her husband and her household.  Some tried to appease the person she believed to be the culprit with ale after she asked for alms and said the person would heal.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of taking the profit off of someone's cow.  Cursing and quarrelling about cattle.  Dispute over a borrowed 'Killtreis' when grinding cornes.  The usual quarrel, curse, harm.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: accused of flyting.  And made sarcastic comments about the Devil.  People refered to her 'as ane banished witche'

FolkNotes: Someone took a lock of her hair.  Description of a ritual where she took 3 cows tail hairs, 3 of her pubic hairs, and 3 hairs from her papys and said 'cum butter, cum' in order to move the profits from one person to another.  When one of her accusers was going home late one evening he met a number of cats and claims to have seen her face on one of the cats.  Appeasment with a bannock.
DiseaseNotes: Moved a lot of profits away from one family to another, specifically cows and cornes.  Damaged a plow after quarrelling.  Quarrel over peats.  Took milk away from a cow.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: she stole some peats.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.

Charnotes: Folk healing as primary as details all indicate that accused was a healer or charmer. The church minutes record her accusation as witchcraft but there are no mentions of demonic pact or other features.
FolkNotes: Used eggs and meal to cure a changeling child. In another incident used fire also to identify changeling who was 'ane hundred years old'.
DiseaseNotes: accused of having said verbal curse against victim after he was angry about her daughter taking some of his wood. She also confessed to having received sixpence from Issobell Johnstone, one of the witnesses, in payment for her advice.

Charnotes: pact confessed but no other details
DevilNotes: devil promised her she would want for nothing
FolkNotes: met the devil at oatseedtime (spring).

DevilNotes: said that the devil lay with her and that she was not dreaming.

Charnotes: Although recorded as having confessed to demonic pact there is little other information.
DevilNotes: Entry in presbytery notes that she confessed to the above.

Charnotes: appears to be about charming and healing  as accused confessed to this, but few other details.
FolkNotes: South running water used, no words to be spoken on the way from collecting water or power of healing would be lost. Said that her own child had been taken by the fairies
DiseaseNotes: recorded has having given advice about curing people.

Charnotes: Ker denied all charges so difficult to assess characterisation
DevilNotes: Witness described how Ker took her to a place where the devil appeared in a dreadful shape. According to the witness Ker offered the devil the girl who called on God, whereupon the devil vanished. Ker denied all charges.
FolkNotes: Witness told presbytery that Ker had appeared to her while she was in her bed with her husband and had abused her. The witness then took an illness and later on her knees asked Ker three times for her health. Ker denied all the accusations.  Later entry in the presbytery minutes about another woman (Christian Adie) who was in trouble for having requested her health from Ker.

Charnotes: The accused did try to launch slander charges against one of her accusers.

CaseNotes: No specific numbers mentioned, only several witches from Carriden parish apprehended and further investigations requested.  Ministers are supposed to make enquiries.

Charnotes: Very few details but presbytery notes that incidents of 'grievous malefice' have been associated with her.

CaseNotes: Janet Miller's trial in 1661 mentioned that she had been tried for witchcraft.

Charnotes: because such a large number were accused it is possible there was some form of local dispute involved
CaseNotes: named with 26 others.

Charnotes: charming was one of the accusations so folk healing element but few other details
OtherChargesNotes: accused of charming and witchcraft and told to make public repentance.

DefenseNotes: Entry in presbytery records, 29/2/1644, notes that the accused denied the charges.

Charnotes: No details about accusations or confession
DiseaseNotes: She had been consulted by someone in Stow.

CaseNotes: 48 unnamed individuals were accused by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) after she was searched by George Cathie. The presbytery of Biggar were sceptical about her testimony and brought her to confront those she had named. They found many inconsistencies in her account and after prayer she confessed that she had only accused innocent people because Cathie had promised to prolong her life if she did so. The 48 individuals were therefore not pursued any further.  The case against them was dropped by the presbytery on 29/12/1649.

DevilNotes: The demonic pact was suspected but few details

Charnotes: Named as witch in kirk session records but accused of giving advice about healing charms for sick children
DiseaseNotes: Recorded as having told three woman how to heal their sick children

CaseNotes: 1 man and 3 woman from Whittingehame were executed.  The execution was attended by the minister.
note that 10 witches burnt in Dunbar and that they were witnessed by a minister.

Several witches mentioned = 3 un-named. They were mentioned several times as trial process took some months but the presbytery records did not list their names.  They refer to a trial held at Jedburgh at which ministers assisted/attended.  Then they were recorded as executed on 16/1/1650 at Oxnam.

DiseaseNotes: Confessed to malefice done to several neighbours but no details

CaseNotes: On 12/6/1650 the presbytery minutes recorded that 4 people in Castleton (in the presbytery of Langholm) were suspected of witchcraft and incantation. No names were recorded in the presbytery minutes.  Then on 26/6/1650 ministers were supposed to assist in the execution of the suspects.

Charnotes: Seems to have got into trouble because she advised people to use healing rituals.
FolkNotes: Entries record that she advised the use of the blood and feathers of a black hen as a healing charm. Note: black cocks were used to cure the falling sickness but there is no mention of the illness or symptoms she was treating.
DiseaseNotes: No details about the symptoms of illness which she could cure.

Charnotes: Although the Devil was not mentioned specifically it seems that the descriptions of fairies indicated demonic involvement. The king of fairies seemed to = the Devil.
DevilNotes: Mentioned that man in black clothes made her go forward and was at meetings with them all. She also referred to one man being the king of fairies who lay with her. She was asked if his nature was hot or cold to which she replied that it was cold. Told minister that she renounced her baptism to the king of fairies.
MeetingNotes: A number of cats came to her house which turned into men and women. Also went with a group of male and female fairies and one man had sex with her and another woman.
FolkNotes: Used water from St Mungo's well to heal her father and spoke verse/charm.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed she and others had caused death of Mr James Ross and one of his children. This may have been the James Ross who was minister at Livingston and who died in 1641.

Charnotes: Demonic as primary as it seems those involved may have read fairies as meaning the Devil or devils. The Devil was only mentioned once compared to several mentions of fairies.
DevilNotes: She confessed that she put her own hand on the crown of her head and the other upon the sole of her foot and declared all betwixt the two over to a black man with black clothes and that the devil appeared to her.
FolkNotes: Used term 'good neighbours' who wore green kirtalls. The fairies wanted a nurse for one of their own offspring. BP told them to go to a neighbour's house but the woman would not go with them and so her child was killed. This may indicate a changeling type motif but it is not mentioned specifically.
DiseaseNotes: One of the company whirled them all in the wind. Woman in green put sickness on one of her neighbours. She put whirl wind in the house of one of her neighbours and caused the woman to 'rattell till death'.

CaseNotes: 'a great many persons' from Musselburgh, Dalkeith, Newbattle, Newton (+ Woomet) and Duddingston but no number or names specified, number calculated as three from each place.  So that is 5 x 3 = 15.  The Privy Council records note that the accused men and women were imprisoned and had already confessed.  A commission of justiciary was issued after petitions from heritors and others from the different parishes.

Charnotes: no details but examined by pricker
Had been examined by pricker for marks.
DevilNotes: She was pricked, so they were looking for a Devil's mark.

Charnotes: The information is limited apart from the slandering and counter slandering. The implication is that the minister believed she had caused his ill-health.
DiseaseNotes: Minister Peter Rae requested her to give him back his health. He also appears to have scratched her on the forehead in order to identify her as a witch.
OtherChargesNotes: Kirkpatrick and minister involved in complex slander and counter slander case.

CaseNotes: Nine unnamed executed for witchcraft and ministers were ordered to assist.

Charnotes: Nothing about accusation or confession.
Noted as having confessed to pact and renunication of baptism but no details from confession or accusation
DevilNotes: Commission records that accused confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism, but no details.

Charnotes: Demonic pact and renunciation of baptism noted in RPC but no details of confession or accusations.
DevilNotes: RPC entry records that accused confessed to demonic pact and renunciation of baptism but no specific details of confession.

Charnotes: recorded as having confessed pact and renunciation ot baptism but no details from confession

CaseNotes: Several people in the parish of Caerlaverock suspected of witchcraft. Only one person named in presbytery records - Bessie Heslope, C/JO/2898.  Presbytery told about number of suspected witches in Caerlaverock. Committee investigated, 27/3/1705, but unsure whether witchcraft proven. Details sent to Queen's Advocate who replied that there were no grounds for criminal process. Presbytery drop the matter on 26/7/1705.

Charnotes: Complicated case as a number of people from the McLean family accused. There may have been some family rivalry between the McLeans and Chisholms and the Chisholms wanted to acquire the lands belonging to the group. Claimed that the McLeans had been 'kindly tenants' for several hundred years.

MeetingNotes: Confessed that some of the company went to Saltoun with candles.

CaseNotes: Referred to as 'the witches of Douglas'. No number given so averaged as 3 suspects.  Note in the Presbytery minutes that brethren were to be sent to Lanark to apprehend the suspects. No details about what happened.

Charnotes: Accused by Janet Coutts, who with George Cathie (pricker) named a large number of people who were later shown to be innocent. In McBirnie's case, however, some neighbours did accuse her of being the cause of some illness and death.
DiseaseNotes: accused of causing William Brown (slaterer) to fall of a house and break his neck after she had exchanged evil words with him. After another falling out with a neighbour she cursed them and prayed that there might be 'blood boils'. Daughter later fell ill

Charnotes: Named by Janet Coutts along with several others
One of the many people denounced by Janet Coutts
One of the many denounced by Janet Coutts
One of several denounced by Janet Coutts
Named as a witch by Janet Coutts

He was suspected then became a star witness.  Not prosecuted.  Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
CaseNotes: Accused but not indicted for witchcraft.  Instead he and his brother were witnesses.  Deemed too young to have made a viable pact with the Devil.  Was not indicted with the large group on 13/4/1697 or tried with the seven who actually stood trial on 12/5/1697.  He was mentioned on the last day of that trial (19/5/1697) in the closing arguments.

Charnotes: The accusations against the two women were not proved by witnesses and the charges dropped. The accuser had to make public repetance.
DevilNotes: Accused of having the devil's mark but there was no evidence and the charge was dropped.
DiseaseNotes: Was accused of having caused the death of a woman but the charge was not proven.

Charnotes: The accusations against the two women were not proven by witnesses and the accuser had to make public repentance.

MeetingNotes: Note that the accused had confessed to attending meetings with the devil.
CaseNotes: MacDonald 'The Witches of Fife' (East Linton, 2002) p. 109 indicates that she tried to clear her name in 1654 after being investigated in 1649.

MeetingNotes: Records note that accused confessed to meetings with the devil but no details.

CaseNotes: Un-named witches from Dysart and Fife. Presbytery directed the baillies of Dysart to ensure the suspects were watched and brought to trial.
Unnamed suspects in 2 parishes (Navar and either Strathcathro or Lethnot) in presbytery of Brechin.

DevilNotes: Foullthief (or ?foulfiend) - the devil - appeared as a man in her own house. It kissed her but she withdrew from it. Asked how she was able to do so since he was a spirit and she was only flesh and blood. Answered she was very strong.
DiseaseNotes: Accused confessed to causing death of woman and a horse, burning a mill and stealing milk but denied that she had caused the sinking of a ship.

Charnotes: Document implies that suspect may have caused an episode of madness in another woman who received an 'act of witchcraft'.
DiseaseNotes: Accused appears to have cast a 'madness' on another woman who then appears to have pestered a man from the town.

Charnotes: No details about accusations.
First in trouble with the presbytery for charming, although no details given about what kind of charming she carried out.
FolkNotes: entry records that she was accused of 'turning the fyne'?

Charnotes: Very little information but the accused was consulted by 1 other to carry out a charm so that they would get the profit back from 'the danke' which was formerly theirs.
DiseaseNotes: Consulted by 2 others to help them get profit back from property that was previously theirs.

CaseNotes: Unnamed witches from Tarbat, presbytery of Tain, mentioned in presbytery records - recorded as 3. Minister to write south for advice about the case but no further details in records.
I think these suspects from Thurso are the same as C/EGD/2461, C/EGD/2462, C/EGD/2085, C/EGD/2086, C/EGD/2087 and C/EGD/2088, who all have their own records. I have recorded this total as zero.

Charnotes: Accused appears to have been refused alms but also consulted for healing advice. The whole family appear to have been unpopular and asking for charity.
FolkNotes: Accused appears to have advised a man to go to Sandness church, and sit in the dark and smoke some tobacco and he would be cured of a sickness, which he claimed had been caused by being given a banock by one of the Ratter sisters.
DiseaseNotes: She had asked for some corn, which was refused, Told the person that she had got corn from her neighbour the previous year and the neighbour had a very good crop. Implied threat to the crop.
OtherChargesNotes: Presbytery notes that the accused was declared as a 'deluder and abuser of the people'.

Charnotes: The family seems to have been unpopular and asking for alms, which were refused.
FolkNotes: Witnesses claimed she cursed a man saying 'God should swarfin his body and his ground' and later the man's body decayed. Swarf - to faint or swoon. Also told family of sick woman who was having blood let that this would not help her. Woman later died.
DiseaseNotes: Accused appears to have argued/cursed her neighbours after disputes. Later sickness/death blamed on her. Refused alms, child of house took ill and died - witnesses claimed he had a 'blue weed' (?fever).
OtherChargesNotes: Charged with being a 'deluder and abuser of the people'.

Charnotes: She was investigated at the same time as the Ratter family, and appears to have been unpopular because she asked for charity.
FolkNotes: Cursed people but no record of what she said.
DiseaseNotes: Asked if she was a witch, but denied accusation. Was refused lodgings, later the woman of the house took bad dreams and was out of her wits. Watson agreed that she cursed people if they wronged her.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused was charged as being a 'deluder and abuser of the people', in 1708. In 1725 the steward found nothing that would infer the crime of witchcraft but that she was a deluder of the people and he intended to proceed against her.
DefenseNotes: Denied she could be a witch and not know it in 1708.

Charnotes: The Ratter family appear to have been very unpopular, asking for alms and arguing. In Andrew's case the list of harm done was more extensive than his sisters.
DiseaseNotes: Accused shared drink with another man at the peat cutting, man later took ill. Animals took ill or born dead after arguments. Refused butter - cow died later. Given alms (some bread) which he threw in fire, the family then had no calves born alive.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of being a' deluder and abused of the people'.

CaseNotes: Note that Mr James Blair (minister at Portpatrick) and other ministers were to attend to commission for trial of witches the next day. Later reported that this had been delivered.

Charnotes: It seems that Kennedy was consulted to witch another woman to death, but not clear how she did this or if it worked. The consulter claimed that she only did this in order to prove that Kennedy was a witch.
DiseaseNotes: It seems that Kennedy was consulted by another woman to witch 'Mistress Mowat to death' although it is not clear if this worked. Kennedy was promised beef and tobacco if she did it. The consulter got in trouble as well.

FolkNotes: Accused of causing illness of a neighbour. Seen carrying a stoup of water while her hair was loose about her ears. The man also claimed to be troubled by a great number of cats - but does not suggest that Sinclair appeared in the shape of a cat.

Charnotes: Wharrie took the case herself to presbytery. She tied to prove that the witnesses had malice against her. Witnesses claimed that she had cursed them after they had refused to help her with ploughing or prevented her from crossing their land. It seems that the presbytery were not convinced by Wharrie's version but could not really do much with her.
FolkNotes: It was cliamed that she cursed and swore at her victims.
DiseaseNotes: Witnesses claimed she cursed and uttered an 'ill prayer' that a neighbour's wife 'would have many a bloody day'. Also cows would vomit their grass or rowt/rout (bellow) to death. Also wished a man to take the glengore (syphilis).
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Wharrie asked neighbours to help with ploughing. When they refused they claimed she cursed their beasts and ploughs so that they could not use them to plough their own rigs.

CaseNotes: 4 women in Caerlaverock suspected of witchcraft.  Presbytery investigated the suspects and noted that the moderator was to write to the sheriff depute to get commission to secure them 'their due trial'. Mr Paton reported that the sheriff was going to write for the commission but they presbytery felt that they should also write to the Privy Council. No further details.

Un-named witches mentioned by Dumfries presbytery as being in prison. Also named with Janet Wharrie (C/JO/3025).  Presbytery recorded that the group of witches were in prison and Mr Veitch was appointed to send the processes to the King's Advocat. There seems to have been a long delay before Mr Blair reported that the King's advocat said there was nothing so 'momentous as to require a commission to put them to trial'. Ministers appointed to inquire about their imprisonment but no mention if they were released or if the investigation was dropped.

Charnotes: Claimed in Helene Frasser's dittay that Hendersoune was instructed in the pact by Frasser.
DevilNotes: Hendersoune was told to put her hand on her head and foot by Helen Frasser and to 'beteich quhatevir was betwein hir handis to the Devil' and she would want for nothing, but Hendersoune did not confess to this.

Charnotes: Andro Man claimed that Moress had learned his witchcraft from his wife.
Bane's association with Spaldarge seems to have condemned her although Bane herself seems to have named quite a few others.
DevilNotes: Confessed that her sister Spaldarge had taught her all her skill and witchcraft, and inducted her to the devil's service.
MeetingNotes: In Issobell Richie's dittay it was claimed that Issobell had taken Bane to meetings with the devil and other witches, but no detail from Bane herself.
FolkNotes: With her sister Spaldarge, she seems to have had a vision of a headless man, which they claimed predicted the death of a man. Seen paddling in loch on Nuris Day, throwing water and erd and stane (ritual of land ownership) over her shoulders. Took fire peat from one man's house to her own house and later daughter/son (?) of the man died. Predicted the birth of a child. Did not exchange any greeting with a man who later died. Touched boy on both cheeks, later he died.
DiseaseNotes: Claimed with Issobell Richie she performed acts of malefice. Consulted as midwife to help labour pains, which were transferred to other people. Helped with calf not suckling, but later wife took ill.Cursed man after he said she would burn. He drowned.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused  of cursing a man who had argued and hit her son, Duncan Gardyne.

FolkNotes: gave Issobell Richie a magic belt which if it was ?lost (tyne) would cause the death of bearded men. It was claimed that the belt was a sign of the devil.

Charnotes: Implicated by assocation with her mother (M. Bane) who was burnt for witchcraft.
FolkNotes: Accused of having caused her daughter-in-law's illness, which was made worse with some milk that was given to her by Rogie's own mother (M. Bane). Was seen to be carrying out some strange ritual of measuring some land and building a cairn of stones and also casting 'yerd and stane' over her shoulder. Erd and stane was a symbolic ritual associated with land ownership. Rogie did not answer the person who saw her carry out the ritual, who then took ill and died. An image of a man, made of soft lead (?wax/clay) was found in her purse.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having cast an illness onto her daughter-in-law (aided by her mother Margaret Bane). Caused oxen and horse of a male neighbour to run wild and die.

MeetingNotes: meeting the same as several others which were ascribed to Margaret Bane. There does not appear to be any evidence from Robbie about the meetings. Bane claimed Robbie went with her mother and they all dacned round the grey stone.
FolkNotes: Accused of having caused the death of a woman by giving her some mutton that Robbie and her mother (Margaret Og) had bewitched. Also accused of having carried out a special ritual (?protective) with her mother. They threw a knife 3 times over a cow while it was at the bull ?to ensure a fertile union.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having aider her mother bewitch and cause the death of Lady Auchinhuiff by giving her some mutton that was bewitched,

FolkNotes: Accused of having spoken a curse, which then caused a man's horse to fall, break its bones and later die. Also claimed to know how to keep a man's health. Take a cog of water, put three straws in it and put it on the back of a sick cow. Then take some water and put it in the cow's mouth, then put an arm down the cow's throat, which will cure a cow. Also accused of throwing water three times for an evil purpose. Was able to locate lost/stolen money. Claimed that she predicted an outbreak of smallpox.
DiseaseNotes: To preserve health carry the bones of a linnet in clothing as a form of talisman.

Charnotes: The accusations about Paplay come from the questioning of another suspect (Barbara Boundie). No details seem to have come from Paplay herself and her son denied all the charges. Bowndie then claimed that she had been encouraged to name other 'honest' women in return for her own life.

DevilNotes: Said the devil appeared in several diverse shapes
MeetingNotes: She later denied that she had attended the meeting and dancing at Muness. Her stories seem to have got confused as she later retracted most of it and claimed she had been urged to name others
FolkNotes: Her statement said that she had been speechless for 1 day and people had said she had been taken by the fairies, she denied this. She denied that she was able to identify other witches.
Accused of being able to locate stolen goods but no details.

DiseaseNotes: Most of the accusations relate to disputes over cows. Neighbours accused her of causing illness and death of cows after arguments. Also one case of healing human.

DevilNotes: She confes ed to meeting the fair folk, then the devil appeared as an angel but also in the form of a human male, who she named. She confessed that the 'fair folk' and the angel offered to protect her if she served them.
MeetingNotes: The meetings were with the 'fair folk' and attended by herself and several others including Richie Graham. There is a lot about food.
FolkNotes: Claimed to have used rowan tree and a piece of a dead person's finger to cure the worm. Fairies offered her food but she refused it. Her husband took ill, then her baby was replaced with a changeling. She refused to feed it and threw it in the fire. She then promised to serve the 'fair folk' in return for her child. Said the saw Richie Graham at meetings with the 'fair folk' as well as several other people. While in prison she was visited by a man and asked to identify who had stolen his cow's milk. The man and the woman that Watsonne identified were questioned by the presbytery.
DiseaseNotes: Accused and confessed to healing a man of the worm using rowan tree.

Charnotes: Devil's mark found by witch pricker so demonic included.
DevilNotes: Searched for mark but no details.
CaseNotes: Identified by a witch pricker. Larger group named each other. Witch pricker then employed and identified marks on 3 others.

Charnotes: The accusations all came from one other woman, although both accused and accuser produced lots of witnesses, and relate to something to do with giving the other woman malt to make her husband's malt improve but not sure if it worked. McNab herself later confessed to knowing how to make a cow accept a calf that did not belong to her. Characterised as neighbourhood dispute since this was the accuser's main reason.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed that she knew how to make a cow accept another calf. Put the skin of the dead calf onto the other calf before the cow licked it. This is a common enough agricultural practice. Presbytery seem to have thought it might be witchcraft.

DevilNotes: Another woman claimed that there were black dogs at meetings of witches, but Murray said nothing about this.
MeetingNotes: Another woman accused Murray of attending dancing with a group of witches. Murray did not appear to make any statement about this.
DiseaseNotes: Cursed man who later took sick. Also with a woman who died. Told a woman in labour that there were cats in her womb, the woman later died. She agreed that she cursed/argued but denied she caused harm.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: She denied that she had taken away the substance of milk.

DiseaseNotes: Minister of Dalmeny claimed that Lauson had cursed him while on her bare knees.

Charnotes: Accused of observing the Lord's Supper in a Catholic way, although she denied this. No other details of any witchcraft.
FolkNotes: Seems to have been accused of observing the Lord's supper in a papistical way. She denied all charges.

Charnotes: No information about Murray herself but mentioned in a slander case. Woman was slandered that she had consulted Murray who was a suspect of witchcraft. The presbytery noted that Murray had not been convicted of witchcraft at her trial and the case against the other woman was dismissed.

MeetingNotes: Claimed she met the devil at neighbour's house, in the little chalrmer (room), where they shared some wine. Other women present.
CaseNotes: A group of people (including Garner) appear to have been investigated and recorded in the kirk session records. A further 2 were identifed by a pricker but no details about them
There seems to have been a group (including Boswell) investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details.

DevilNotes: Confessed that she had carnal relations with the devil and he was as 'cold as ice'.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing the death of a child.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of causing the death of a child but not of child murder.
CaseNotes: Part of a group (including Potter) who were investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details

DevilNotes: Confessed that she made a covenant with the devil
CaseNotes: Named in a group (including Lodge) who were investigated and tried at Dysart. The accusations stemmed from one and spread out. Another 2 were identified by a pricker but few details.
A number of people were investigated by the kirk session, some were found guilty, others searched for the mark but the fate of most is unknown.

DevilNotes: Was searched and mark seems to have been found, but no details.
FolkNotes: She was requested to take the sickness off a child, who it was thought she had made ill.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having made a child ill after a dispute and requested to restore the child's health by its mother.
CaseNotes: A group including (Burt) were investigated by kirk session. Another 2 were identified by pricker but few details.

Charnotes: Demonic included as KS noted he had been searched.
DevilNotes: KS records that a mark was found on him but no details.
MeetingNotes: Male witness told kirk session that Quhyt had been drinking in Kirkcaldy although there does not seem to have been any demonic involvement in this drinking sesssion.
CaseNotes: Part of a group who were investigated by kirk session. Another 3 were identified by pricker.

Charnotes: No details but witch pricker claimed to find devil's mark.
DevilNotes: KS notes that she was searched and a mark found but no details.
CaseNotes: Indentified by witch pricker. There was bigger group who named each other. Witch pricker was then employed and identified some of the group and 3 others.

Charnotes: Investigated for use of charms
DiseaseNotes: Investigated for use of charms but no details.

Charnotes: Charges appear to relate to charming rituals, which may have gone wrong. There is no mention of any demonic elements.
FolkNotes: Used a belt as part of a healing ritual (met the belt).

Charnotes: Important note about process, they were involved in watching and warding (i.e. sleep deprivation) to try and get confessions.  Also a pricker was brought in to test for the Devil's mark.
CaseNotes: Investigations by Stow kirk session. No names listed. Group were imprisoned and there was ongoing discussions about watching and warding. Kirk session wrote to presbytery trying to get financial support for the trial process.  On 8/1649 the situation was referred to the local magistrate.

Charnotes: This is all about healing but the presbytery referred to it as witchcraft.
FolkNotes: Claimed to heal the gut using water and butter.
DiseaseNotes: Claimed he healed the gut and learned it from another called (illegible) Campbell. His mother could cure broken bones?

Charnotes: Appear to have been about using charms, which later became accusation of witchcraft, but no details.
There seems to have been quite a lot of healing or failed healing but a lot of the accusations seem to have involved neighbourhood disputes. Most of the witnesses were men.
DiseaseNotes: Descriptions of healing rituals but most of the accusations involved either failed healing, transfer of sickness or causing illness after dispute.

Charnotes: Named by Jonet Tailzour but many witnesses gave evidence about her malefice, which often resulted from disputes and insults.
DiseaseNotes: She seems to have cursed and quarrelled quite a bit and accusations revolved around perceived harm after arguments.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused of harming goods and gear after insults and disputes.

Charnotes: She was noted as being consulted for childbirth, so was most likely involved in midwifery.  But we dont have any specific information about Drummond other than what Paton said in her trial.
